Paul Rudd also plays a complex character that is overly likable. Jack Nicholson plays Rudd's dad, and the biggest complaint I have with the movie is that he's not in it enough. This movie does something that is hard to do, a funny, romantic comedy that is enjoyable for both men and women. I think that a lot of that has to do with the casting. I give it a B.

Would I watch again? - I think I actually would.

Really flat characters, bad acting, VERY bad and predictable story...

The only good parts are the ones with Owen Wilson, he's as good as usual, but Rudd and Witherspoon are just bad. Like really bad. Rudd's acting in particular ruins this movie.

And why do they feature Jack Nicolson on the cover? He plays such a minor role! Remember Christmas when you were a child? You get a nice packet, wrapped in nice paper, perhaps even with a nice picture on it, letting you think you know what you get? But when you open it, it's just a pair of woolen socks that itch really badly. And the picture was unrelated to the content. That's what this move is like. It really made me feel angry. It even made me register to IMDb.com, just to give this movie the worst rating possible. I wanted to give it minus 10 stars, bud sadly that's not possible.
Nyc dialogues scenes and a good feel movie. Characters are well crafted and reachable
Not a fan of Rom Coms to be begin with this movie is just awful. The dialogue, the plot, the cliches. It wasn't really even funny, was it mean to be? Waste of good actors, stay away !

The marketing was way off on this movie. This movie could have done better in theaters of not for Bad bad marketing. Obviously someone didn't understand James L Brooks audience and tried to go for Reese Witherspoon's fans instead. Not a smart move.Should have been pumped as a James L Brooks movie. Definitely should have featured the fact that Reese Witherspoon plays an athlete!! I didn't see it in the theaters because it just seemed like that stock character Reese usually plays. Owen Wilson, Paul Rudd, Jack--great acting!!! Everyone's in limbo and trying to move forward through uncertainty, which many people can relate to. Locations are beautiful. Owen Wilson is excellent as the affable cad. Not as well-paced as As Good as It Gets, but it's definitely a good flick for movie night.
The writing in this movie is not good .The pacing is too slow ,and the camera angles are awkward.At least the acting is okay.

review_title: Doesn't satisfy - as a chick flick, comedy, or anything else
review_detailed_main:
Paul Rudd and Owen Wilson elicit a few chuckles, but Reese Witherspoon just makes you shake your head. There's no chemistry between her and either actor, her sad situation (upon which the movie is based) is really not so sad, and either due to poor acting or poor writing, it's hard to take interest in her character.

The one really poignant scene in the movie is between supporting actress Kathryn Hahn as Annie and actor Lenny Venito as Al. As another reviewer mentioned, this scene really eclipses the rest of the movie - which is odd, since these two characters are underdeveloped in the script. Why didn't we watch a movie about them (plus Paul Rudd maybe) instead of waste our time on the other plot lines?

review_title: as far as romantic comedy's....utter failure. :-)
review_detailed_main:
having seen enough romantic comedies, i feel i can honestly say that this piece of 2-hour crap is the worst i have ever seen. there, i said it.

comedies are supposed to be funny right? everyone's view of comedy is relative i know but c'mon...not one single thing that i myself consider funny happened. and i only watched half of it!!!. i truly couldn't stomach watching the other hour.

i agree with the one person regarding James brooks...for-shame James, for-shame. :-( definitely not your best movie you've ever had a hand in.

i laughed more watching Hellraiser than i did this movie...lolol...

if i could give a negative rating...i would.

review_title: My 377th Review: Deeply deeply romantic film that defies cynicism
review_detailed_main:
It's not often I go this much against the popular opinion and the critics - but we totally enjoyed this - it has what so many films lack - instead of a super manufactured and polished script - it has SPARK and it has charm - and kookiness, and romance, deep, deep, overwhelmingly fall for the right one, never mind the consequences, romance.

I guess the cynics just find that squirmy. We don't. The chemistry between the leads is wonderful, and Owen Wilson is very good indeed at pulling of the difficult act of the playboy but does so with such insouciance that you have to just laugh and go with it. Rudd and Witherspoon work here, and you'll either get it and feel it, or you'll squirm.

Jack is Jack and his timing is as always perfect.

I say long live love - get to see this - and just enjoy it - that's the answer really - just go with it, enjoy it, and let the romance get to you - it's a wonderful feeling when it does....

The reviews were mixed, so I went for it. I love Paul Rudd, and Reese and Owen are usually good. This movie just doesn't make sense. The dialogue is weird and all over, there is something off about these actors who normally can be really funny, charming, and great in their roles. I love romantic comedies and even cheesy ones, this felt like neither.

review_title: Laugh out loud film, great acting
review_detailed_main:
A preliminary comment: I just don't understand all these bad reviews. Are these reviewers the same people who flock to Jason Statham movies, Angelina Jolie movies and SAW movies?

OK, it's not the greatest rom-com ever, but it has four superior points going for it, and they more than carry the day.

1. There are dozens of great, even laugh-out-loud lines in it, written by some very smart, funny people. And all the characters get their share, and deliver them perfectly. Great writing like this makes a movie delightful and delicious.

2. This is the best acting by Jack Nicholson in years and years. He's at the top of his form and a pure joy to behold. It's a performance like his in this movie that inspires people to want to become actors, to try to emulate what he can accomplish when he's at his very best. I'll see this movie again just to watch his subtle, emotional, wonderful elevation of his character far beyond the highest expectations and hopes of the writers and director.

3. Owen Wilson. For years he's just cruised through role after role delivering lines, relying on his smirk and physical presence to carry him, and becoming one of the most boring actors in the business. Here he absolutely shines. He acts! He acts the simpleton, but with the simplest of deliveries, and with a control and restraint (that seem new to him) which are perfect for his character. Wilson is challenged to play a purely straightforward, intelligent, friendly, honest, clueless misogynist, and he carries it off like aces. He doesn't go for a laugh once, but is the funniest thing about this whole funny film.

4. Kathryn Hahn. WOW! What a tour de force by an actress who has spent so long delivering straight lines to carry stories along. If Owen Wilson shines, then Kathryn Hahn must be the very sun itself. Her part is limited but she throws off sparks in every scene she's in. There are many highlights in this film, and all her scenes are among them. I quickly found myself waiting and hoping for her next appearance.

And frankly, while I'm not giving them their own numbered paragraphs, Reese Witherspoon and Paul Rudd, who have the workhorse roles and the responsibility for carrying this movie on their shoulders, really come through. She in particular looks great, better than ever, and they both give natural performances with difficult lines. These two are starting to put their contemporaries in the shade, blow their doors off, leave them in the dust, outdistance them by furlongs, etc., etc., etc.

So let the moron reviewers have their say, but close your ears to their ignorance. This is not the best romantic story since Adam and Eve, but it's good and it's funny and it'll soon be one of the staple features in all the acting schools in America.

We couldn't watch more than half of this movie. The acting is wooden, there's zero chemistry, and it isn't worth your time. I usually give a movie a chance, hoping it'll get better if I just hang in there, but this one was so bad we didn't care what happened in the end. Don't say I didn't warn you!

I love Reese Witherspoon and almost all of the movies she has starred in so I was really looking forward to seeing this movie.

Sadly, I ended up being very disappointed.

The movie just dragged on and on.

To make matters worse, none of the characters in the storyline were very likable and I found myself not caring which love interest the female lead ended up with as both male leads were quite irritating.

As far as I am concerned, this movie was a total flop.

Don't bother wasting your money to see it - you will likely end up falling asleep!

It starts like a sports movie turns in to a Wall Street thriller and ends like a love story. Little strange for a mundane romantic movie yet it's interesting than it looks.

Lisa who is a softball player gets cut from the next year's team which forces a change in her life. Without knowing what to do she finds out that a decent guy from corporate world who is currently being investigated for federal fraud and a millionaire base ball player starts to interest her. Confused enough in the middle of these two who are completely different characters from each other she struggles to find a balance and choose who is correct for her.

The plot is short and sweet just like in many romantic movies out there and so do the acting and characters themselves. There is nothing special to go crazy about 'How do you know me' but there is something which will make you hang in to it. However when it comes to acting Paul Rudd (Who plays George the corporate guy) is quite remarkable here. It seems like he got the correct role which he surely enjoyed portraying. And the wonderful appearance of Jack Nicolson lights up the story as well.

Lisa played by Reese Witherspoon is a strong character which tries to reason with her own self when something goes wrong. Reese pulls it out quite well. And at times she proves that being positive can actually make you though difficult situations in life. (And dating two guys at once helps too!)

You won't be taking anything away after watching it for a whole two hours which is quite a bit longer than usual for this kind of flick. You can have some good laughs and be light hearted with 'How do you know me'.

More at flickshout.blogspot.com

review_title: Dropping in on some complicated lives
review_detailed_main:
James L. Brooks has given us some very fine films (Terms of Endearment, As Good As It Gets) and some mediocre (at best) ones - like Spanglish, The Simpsons Movie and numerous TV series. The odd thing about this much maligned HOW DO YOU KNOW is that it seems to be searching to find a reason for being mad - often to the point of feeling as though Brooks wrote the script as he went. For this viewer the film is not as bad as the audiences and critics say, but it is definitely one of Brooks' memorable works. The characters he created are for the most part losers who manage to get along in life because of an occult optimism. That part is refreshing.

Lisa (Reese Witherspoon) is a much loved Pro Softball player whose ego is badly bruised when she is cut from the new team. She dates Matty (Owen Wilson), a wealthy major league baseball pitcher who is either horrifically naive or completely clueless when it comes to relating to Lisa. Concurrently we meet George (Paul Rudd), a bright but emotionally ill- equipped businessman who has just been indicted in his work for his father Charles's (Jack Nicholson) company - apparently for something he did not do. Just as this vulnerable guy needs support he is dumped by his girlfriend and must move out of his place to lesser digs with the help of his devoted assistant Annie (Kathryn Hahn) who is very pregnant but unwed. Lisa meets George on a date arranged by well-meaning friends, but Lisa is 'committed' to Matty. Some chemistry between Lisa and George develops, Matty makes moves to change and invites Lisa to move in, George and his father duel over the indictment, and finally the 'sort of love' triangle finds a shaky center and Pow! the movie is over.

Witherspoon makes the best of her odd role and Paul Rudd restores some glory to his dwindling cinematic repertoire. Owen Wilson is Owen Wilson, and Jack Nicholson looks like he is one the wrong movie set. Part of this little film is smart, but it just never quite gels. How do we know? Just watch it with low expectations and be surprised here and there.

Grady Harp

Despite my intense & unconditional love for Paul Rudd (and Jack Nicholson for that matter), this is a terrible f*ing movie. That's it. Not funny when it supposed to be funny. Not heartfelt or cut when it intends to be such. It's terrible.

I have no idea what this movie was about. The acting was sub par and I blame this on the director and the script.

To take Jack Nicholson and screw up a movie is quite a feat. But to take him, and Witherspoon, and Wilson and put Rudd in the same movie and it goes no where is really a leap.

I do have some questions that perhaps someone can answer: 1. What was the whole assistant and her pregnant got to do with the story? 2. Why did he give her the watch and have this big party and then she says she wants to 'hang out' with Rudd? He goes from a strong person to a real wozz in the movie? 3. Witherspoon moves in and out that the door man must have had a time figuring out if she lived there or was visiting. Does she not sit and discuss why Owen made the comment? Is he not allowed to make a mistake as this is what appeared to be his first real live-in relationship so he is new to all of this.

Witherspoon's here comes off like a whinny self-absorbed (rymns with witch) Notice that I did not use the names of the people in the movie, because this was not a movie but a total waste of such great talent. Each could have gotten into phone booths and called in their parts.

There was no depth and there was no reason to have any feelings for any of the people in the movie. Disjointed, mixed up, went no where and a waste of time.

I only give it 2 stars because of the actors in the movie and it is not their fault.

DUD!!

review_title: A Good Comedy Drama Romance That May Be Too Cerebral For Some
review_detailed_main: This comedy-drama starring Reese Witherspoon, Paul Rudd, and Owen Wilson directed by James R. Brooks offers up a romantic triangle that at its core is a serious, cerebral look at relationships with strong humorous overtones. Unlike Reese Witherspoon's romantic triangle in This Means War an action, comedy thriller two years later, Witherspoon's character in How Do You Know is much more involved and three-dimensional. This film is for some unsettling with unresolved subplots, especially when it comes to Witherspoon's career. And unlike the more acceptable as well as delightfully twisty romantic comedy triangle of My Girlfriend's Boyfriend (2010) with Alyssa Milano, How Do You Know presents two credible suitors but whose relationship with Witherspoon's character is both convoluted, quite well executed and realistic yet somewhat unsatisfactorily resolved and off-putting. At the same time, it is just this uneasy sense of denouement that makes this movie critically stronger and more substantive, if not plainly audience pleasing. For those looking for an extended look at romantic relationships involving two credible male characters that may recall one's own relational conflicts and torments, this movie puts you in the middle of it all.

review_title: Fanaticalaboutfilms Review: How Do You Know
review_detailed_main:
It's your usual affair- guy meets girl, guy falls for girl, there are some ups and downs inbetween but eventually guy and girl get together. Now you are wondering why I've spoilt the ending for you? Well I haven't because there are two guys in this movie in a lovely romance triangle.

Lisa (Reese Witherspoon) plays our indecisive femme fatale with George (Paul Rudd) and Matty (Owen Wilson) the men doting after her. The movie compromises of 2 separate story lines that eventually merge. In one Lisa is a USA softball player who has just been dropped from the national team and Matty, her current boyfriend, is a major-league baseball star. He is a player both on and off the pitch and doesn't totally understand the workings of a relationship but is trying to for her.

In the other George, like Lisa is going through his own problems as he is being indited by the government and faces some serious charges if convicted and has also been dumped by his girlfriend. However due to a series of phone calls and chance encounters George keeps meeting Lisa which leads to the 2 men competing for her affection in their own unique ways.

George's father (acted by Jack Nicholson) and Annie, George's secretary (impressively portrayed by Kathryn Hahn) are the outlets from the romantic side of the story and bring with them some of the better moments in the movie from a comic point of view. It seems that this kind of role is starting to become Wilson's mainstay in the movies with the majority of his performances being based around the slightly error prone man (Hall Pass, You Me And Dupree). He never really impresses me and the chemistry is not there from the start unlike with Rudd who puts in a convincing performance with Witherspoon.

I felt that the plot surrounding this is slightly more in-depth than some of the other romcoms out there but by no means that complex that it becomes hard to follow. It just tended to be a bit more detailed than I was expecting before I sat down to watch it. This could be due to it's 2 hour length though which is quite a long time to invest in a romcom that does drag at points.

This isn't in the same league as the last movie where James L Brooks and Nicholson teamed up (As Good As It Gets) but if you feel slightly brain dead and want to waste a few hours then this might just do the trick. If there had been a bit more comedy then it might have faired slightly better.

For further reviews feel free to check out: http://www.fanaticalaboutfilms.com

review_title: Despite a Stellar Trio of Stars, Brooks Sags This Time Around with a Meandering Triangle Yarn
review_detailed_main:
Somewhere hidden in this overlong, often exasperating 2010 comedy is a small-scale independent film about flawed characters trying to take charge of their lives when they really never had the control to begin with. That more intimate movie is the one I wanted to see, but veteran director/screenwriter James L. Brooks ("Terms of Endearment") appears focused on showing the messiness of their lives by adding incidental characters and overinvolved subplots that do little to enrich the romantic triangle at the story's heart. This approach could have worked better as a TV series where you would have a reason to come back every episode, but I think Brooks makes a fundamental mistake in thinking that such an approach works over a two-hour running time because the emotional payoff feels marginal. That's not to say the movie isn't smart, insightful, and funny in its scattershot way, but it's just too unwieldy to love.

Similar to the structure of Brooks' "Broadcast News", the meandering plot focuses on 31-year-old Lisa Jorgenson, a popular career softball player who suddenly gets cut from the Team USA roster. Cast adrift from her one passion in life, she starts dating Matty Reynolds, a self-indulgent A-Rod-type pro baseball player with a classic case of Peter Pan Syndrome. In this tenuous situation comes George Madison, a financial executive who first alienates Lisa by giving her a courtesy call just to tell her he is seeing someone else. However, his world comes crashing down when he becomes the target of a criminal investigation for corporate malfeasance at a company run by his conniving tycoon father Charles Madison. George's shallow girlfriend dumps him, so he calls Lisa for what turns out to be a disastrous blind date. At the same time, they haphazardly bond over their respective misfortunes just as Matty tries to acquit himself of his selfish, womanizing ways. The romantic triangle is set up for further complications until the eventual resolution.

The stars perform admirably under the circumstances. In Lisa, Reese Witherspoon finds a role that accommodates her likable steeliness with a gently probing vulnerability. Playing Matty, Owen Wilson comes across more predictably amusing as the supreme man-boy so proud of his glimmers of maturity that he has to announce them out loud to Lisa. Paul Rudd probably fares the best of the trio as George simply because he has that schlubby everyman demeanor down to an art, and there is a flattering hint of Jack Lemmon circa 1960 in his performance. Jack Nicholson returns in his fourth role in a Brooks film, this time playing the subsidiary role of Charles with his mastery of sleaze intact. Kathryn Hahn portrays George's loyal and very pregnant assistant Annie in a little too broad a manner for the company she keeps here, but my guess is that Brooks encouraged her to play it that way in order to provide a striking contrast with the introspective workings of the principal characters.

Considering the film's disappointing box office returns, the 2011 DVD offers a surprisingly abundant set of extras - a decent audio commentary by Brooks and cinematographer Janusz Kaminski plus a select scenes commentary with Brooks and Wilson obviously focusing on the actor's scenes as Matty; four deleted scenes; a quick blooper reel; and a fifteen-minute making-of featurette. The Blu-Ray adds an interactive script gallery; a conversation with Brooks and composer Hans Zimmer; more deleted scenes with more Brooks commentary, and another featurette focused on Rudd's character.

review_title: How Do You Know? ........ I don't know, and frankly I Don't care!
review_detailed_main:
Let's get started with this review in a very soft and loving matter,, I HATE THIS MOVIE, AND ITS THE MOST BORING MOVIE OF THE YEAR!!!! OK, now that we've got that out of the way let's start with the review,, Firstly, this movie is a huge disappointment because having a cast that is this talented and a director that has a very good comedic history produce such a film is very depressing.

Secondly, This movie is BORING! It is filled with unfunny lines and silly jokes that will make you go to sleep.

The only reason that I gave this movie a 2/10 and not a 1/10 is because Owen Wilson tries his best with the very bad material given.

Take my advice, DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE!

review_title: Over-the-top offbeat, but somehow it works
review_detailed_main: This film is a strange entry in the romcom genre. The characters are drawn in such broad strokes, with wildly vacillating emotions and odd motives. The story is difficult to connect to for a while, with its bombastic tone. It's novel to see so many very familiar faces in such an offbeat film. Surprisingly, I stayed interested throughout. Somehow the odd tone was never off-putting, The idea of a love triangle involving both an incredibly immature pro athlete and a beleaguered businessman didn't seem ridiculous or stacked. An overdone family business subplot didn't crash the film. There were enough good laughs to carry the film to its conclusion. From the various reviews, I can tell this film polarizes viewers, with some loving and some hating it, I'm more in the middle, though on the positive side; I liked it just fine.

i seem I am not the only one who thought to myself, 'is this movie going to go anywhere or what?' You get one nervous bumbling (Ben Stiller/ Jason Biggs) character per movie. Okay, they had three. Two strong, one turned into that. I have yet to recall a single thing that made me laugh. the fed problem of the character didn't have a strong direction whether it was going to be a court case, a family feud, I mean something. The romance looked as real as if I tapped a guy on the street that announced I wasn't his type and said, "hey, tell her you really like her. I'll give you $50." The father character looked like he should've either 1.went to a therapist 2. family feud 3. mental hospital 4.turned evil character in court or 5.made his son's character change from the shock of the news. But it just stayed stagnet in the hospital never to be broght up again. Man, that movie seriously was boring.

I truly believe this is the worst movie ever made.

Just absolutely painfully terrible.

In no situation, apart from pure masochism and self hatred, should anyone consider watching this movie.

My fingernails have forever scarred my eyeballs due to watching this. If I ever see a copy of this movie I will destroy it in an attempt to save the future of our species.

It contains an absolutely disgusting script. I literally puked up in my mouth at some of the tripe coming out the these normally respected actors mouths. How they all came together to make this horrid pile a steaming fecal matter will forever elude me. Did anyone bother to read the script? Where are their agents to save them from this movie that will forever taint their careers? So sad.

"How Do You Know" is a thoughtful, funny, and romantic dramedy. It covers young people in their early thirties having to make tough choices about their life and career, and does it with way more thought and accuracy than something like "Morning Glory"(2010).

The film begins with some interesting parallels. George (Paul Rudd) and Lisa (Reese Witherspoon) have had some unlucky breaks in their careers and their lives are going straight downhill. George is with an analytically-minded girlfriend but she thinks his troubles would be too much for their relationship, meanwhile Lisa is with Matty (Owen Wilson) but he doesn't have enough brain power to care what she's thinking let alone what that would mean. It ends up playing out like a romantic comedy rather than a drama, but there is still a lot of thought and simple honesty to the whole thing.

This is the role that I have been waiting for for Paul Rudd. He is still very funny but this is about his character and what he's going to do with the crap that life has handed him. Witherspoon was cute and likable. Sometimes their simple messages were too simple and things got a little too neat, but the actors were all quite funny and I thoroughly enjoyed "How Do You Know".

review_title: Enjoyable if you're a fan of Paul Rudd or Reese Witherspoon
review_detailed_main: Paul Rudd really does have enough screen charisma to carry any movie. If it weren't for him, and of course the still underrated Reese Witherspoon, there wouldn't be anything worth viewing here. The top-billed actors separated this film from such drek as, He's Just Not That Into You, or other mindless romantic comedies. After a dismal theater run, This movie continues to get a bad reputation based on non-existent word-of-mouth, or its criminally over-bloated budget, but beneath it all, it's a some what enjoyable experience. All headlining actors created likable enough characters and you can't really ask for more in a movie such as this. Not being a huge fan of this genre, I felt it hits all of its marks and works as a date-night movie for fans of the main cast.

review_title: It will disappoint you thoroughly. It is a waste of your time. No real plot...it is just random scenes and feelings and thoughts thrown together for 2 hours.
review_detailed_main: If someone held a gun to my head and asked me to watch this movie again, i would still beg to only watch half of it! Reese Witherspoon acts awkward in the entire movie, almost like this is the first role she has acted in. I mean honestly, can we take her seriously as a hard core, tough, guarded, softball player....NO!!! I should have known then it was going to be AWFUL, however Paul Rudd had absolutely no spark, I felt no connection to his character whatsoever. The only person who gave this movie a little bit of humor or life was Owen Wilson's character. I firmly agree with another post i read, it started out with a great idea that failed, which is an understatement.

I'm not the type of person that is super critical about movies. To be honest, I enjoy most of the movies I watch. But even just a few minutes into How Do You Know I could sense just how bad this movie was. In the beginning of the movie the plot jumps around with absolutely no apparent connection at all. The plot, like most "chick flicks" is pretty predictable. I found it completely annoying that Witherspoon's character spoke in mostly clichés and motivational sayings. I understand that was part of her character's competitive softball playing lifestyle, but I kept waiting for something even remotely genuine to be said. Paul Rudd's character was just odd. He's supposed to be odd, but it just got old after a while. Nickolson's character had a sort of sub-plot going on that I felt should have gotten more detail and focus. I honestly felt bad watching this movie for all of the actors, because generally I think most of them are pretty good. I kept hoping this movie would end (and part of that was due to the fact it was kind of long). I very seldom found it funny, even when you could tell that the writers were trying so hard to be funny. All in all, save your time and money and don't watch this movie.

review_title: A touching honest, at times very funny out of sync movie worth seeing
review_detailed_main:
The core story is fine... the leads are well cast... the acting OK... the direction horrible.

Sometimes is it very hard to pinpoint why a movie misses being really good... has really fine little moments but never connects them... in the case of "How do you Know," you can start with the silly tile... what it means even if the line is said in the movie I could not tell you.

The background music in the first have is completely crossed with the emotions... irritating even. One thinks all the time... why is this director interrupting these fine actors and actresses with incessant cutting during conversations?

But if I were to really get to why this film almost makes it... but fails in the end...it comes down to the director's misunderstanding of Resses Witherspoon.

Resse is a woman now... she needs to be herself... the girl next door that we all love... but has to transition in our minds to the more serious emotionally deep women that we want her to be. And Reese has to realize that the reason people love her in movies is that she is.... joyous inside and empathetic to others... it comes across so easily for her characters.

When she brightens up, the movies moves well... when she darkens it loses its way. Nothing wrong with the character... just the mix of emotions seems off and it is not Reese's acting so much as the character is not well drawn.

Owen Wilson is very good with... Reese but is not allowed out of his character's blond arrogant baseball player box.

There is a scene where Reese and Owen are sitting together in his character's kitchen... you can see their potential as actors together... but the director does not know how to bring it out.

Jack Nickelson is wasted in every scene... even disrespected.

Again the directing but also the writing of his character is a parody of other characters Jack has played...but... without the good writing and truth.

How you can have him in your movie and not bring him together on scene more with Reese... as the story demanded... but the director for some reason suppressed... is really really... odd.

There are a few moments that are laugh out loud funny... and several well written... . Paul Rudd... is very good but the strange pacing of the movie which is also a problem throughout... keeps his character from appearing anything more than confused until the very end. We never really feel who he is... Owen comes off a little better if a stereotype for him... Rudd's character's father Nickelson... is a shadow of a on screen person... and Reese struggles throughout the movie with a mostly badly written part, whose actions are shallow in the main.

It goes to show that... even well cast movies... can not carry an only partially well written scrip and never when badly directed.

Still the movie has moments... deep ones even... and is truthful always... it is just that those touching moments are never connected well... in the dynamic of the movie or in the character's lives.

review_title: The play dough story is the best part of this rom com
review_detailed_main:
In part this was an awkward film...but at the same time sincerely sweet (I am thinking of the play dough scene).

Reese Witherspoon plays Lisa, a softball athlete who gets cut from Team USA. It has been her lifelong dream and now she is kind of adrift. Meanwhile, George is being investigated by the Feds for something he didn't do...but because of that he is being iced out by both his company and the company CEO...his father, played by Jack Nicholson.

George and Lisa meet...while both are suffering in their lives and it is decidedly awkward and not their best moments. Lisa is also dating a professional baseball player, played by Owen Wilson, who is nothing more than an adult child.

I had several outbursts of laughter...like when George physically runs away from his father and when one baseball player explains to the other that he knows he's in love when he "wants to wear a condom with the other women". (So very professional athlete!)

Most of this movie was a pass for me...but the contrast of the gifts for Lisa's birthday along with the story that came with the play dough was the redeeming scene in the film. I'm not sure I would classify this as a romantic rom com...but I think people struggling with their place or "what to do next" might appreciate this film.

review_title: Rocky Road Cookie with no flavor
review_detailed_main: Lisa (Reese Witherspoon) has been on the USA Softball Team for many years and her whole life has been devoted to sports as far as she can remember. This year the USA Softball Team Coach has decided to let Lisa go. Confused on what to do, she tries to live a regular life. Normalness journey begins with a relationship with Matty (Owen Wilson) a ladies' man and a major league pitcher. They both decide to try living together but this turns out to be uncharted waters for the both of them. Now there's George (Paul Rudd). George runs his dads business. The Fed's are investigating George for a financial crime that his Dad committed and his Dad (Jack Nicholson) wants his son to do the jail time for him. George meets Lisa in a elevator at the same building where Matty and Charles live. Together they find themselves in a romance that seems to work. Film pace slow, jokes miss-fired, Matty's cluelessness annoying, FBI investigation not needed and George being to dorky, made it a rocky road cookie with no flavor. 2 out of 5 stars.

review_title: 2 good movies smashed together makes a bad one
So deep, that most of the people don't get it
review_detailed_main: This a movie full of moments, dialogs, expressions, situations that really show to much about life, love and parenthood. This is my 4th time I watch this movie and overtime it's getting better. Underrated it's not the word for this movie, its just that people doesn't get it. And let my tell you that Resse its great here, Paul to, and Jack, well maybe it will be his last movie so he's great to, but the big win is James, he it's a master of feelings, he is the best for making me laugh and cry, one of my favorite directors. I will love to hear that James is working in another movie, please do more. I might add that maybe the reason for the people don't get the movie its because they don't want to open their hearts, or simply they don't know how, how do you know? Thanks!!

In the movie when George is talking to Lisa about the Play Doh, he mentions the origin and inventors of Play Doh. He states in the scene that it was created in Central Ohio (AKA Columbus Ohio and Franklin County). However, the movie fact checker missed one. Play Doh was actually developed (created) in Cincinnati, Ohio which is definitely not Central Ohio. So, unfortunately the writer (s) were misinformed about the origin story. Thought I would pass this on to viewers and reviewers of this movie. Otherwise, it was cute, big stars, and a very beautiful Reese Witherspoon. And Jack Nicholson was his usual grouchy self.

review_title: Not a complete waste, but it was overall very disappointing and didn't engage me
review_detailed_main: I wanted to like this film, as I do like Jack Nicholson and although the trailer was uninspiring on the whole I was intrigued in a way. How Do You Know had its moments, but for me it didn't work. It's redeeming qualities come from some beguiling filming and scenery, a nice soundtrack and two good performances from Paul Rudd and Kathryn Hahn, particularly Rudd. The story for starters is very plodding and predictable, with an ending you can smell a mile off, while neither the comedic and romantic aspects work, few of the comedic moments feel natural and the romantic moments are stilted both in pace and flow of the dialogue. The direction(coming from a director with a hit-and-miss resume) is rather characterless and I could not properly connect to the characters, Witherspoon's especially annoyed me. Aside from Rudd and Hahn, the other acting fails to make an impression. Owen Wilson has some likable moments but overdoes it so he comes across as a jerk too much. Jack Nicholson was disappointing, he is a great actor but he looks tired and seems disengaged. It doesn't help that nothing is done to make his character memorable, performance and script-wise, he feels like he's there for the sake of a plot device. Even with my disappointment with Nicholson, it is very little compared to Reese Witherspoon who never seems comfortable in this movie and the whole performance seems forced. All in all, disappointing. 4/10 Bethany Cox

review_title: Disappointed review on "How Do You Know?"
review_detailed_main:
This movie was awful, such a waste of money. I was very disappointed at how boring and pointless it seemed to be. I left towards the end because i was very bored. Acting was not believable at all.

It's unfortunate to see these originally great actors in this horrible movie that seemed to literally have no plot. Honestly, it was a waste of time and i don't recommend seeing this movie....ever. I'm very confused as to why this movie even made it to the theaters in the first place. There were many scenes in the movie that i didn't perceive the reason why they were even in the movie. Reese Witherspoon is an academy award winning actress and i'm sad to say that i am extremely disappointed with her acting in this movie, however; the role she played was a little unlike her usual bubbly, light-hearted roles. This movie sucked. Hope this helps!

review_title: Underrated--full of charm and classic moments

review_detailed_main:
In my romcom period. Sundays are about lightness and crap movies. I think I'm in the minority here, having read some awful reviews, but I had a good time. I know the film is bad. The message is weak. But I found this unexpectedly good and comforting.

Reese Whiterspoon is so warm and delicate, she's doesn't miss. Paul Rudd plays himself, and his romcom version is just peak Paul Rudd. Owen Wilson is my comfort actor and I just need an Owen Wilson "wow" to like a film. Some scenes were really warm and welcoming, with those long dialogues and perfect performances that helped set a tone of authenticity, despite the bad plot.

Hans Zimmer scoring this helped some scenes reach the right amount of emotion. Reese Whiterspoon is climbing the chart of my favourite actors. Really fast.

review_title: If Owen Wilson is the best thing - Oh!
Good movie, not so good acting!
review_detailed_main: Too many people are getting caught up on the big name actors in this film. All in all the acting wasn't as strong as it should have been, and the plot line was a little jumpy at times and contained too much unnecessary dialogue. But the romantic elements presented by this film were endearing. Where more popular movies have only a few touching moments, this film contained a roller coaster of emotions as exhibited by life itself. It shows how having someone to care about can help you forget about your sorrows. The life lessons taught by this film were resounding. Although the acting wasn't awesome, the characters had very peculiar personalities, and it had a creative flair. It beat the standard Barbie and Ken roles of most romances!
There seemed to be too many details being added to the main storyline, making it difficult to follow

Lets start by saying, I had expected so much more, As Good as it Gets is definitely one of the films I like very much in the comedy genre and I had hoped this was up there. Unfortunately it does not have the same intriguing story or the same level of comedian enthusiasm, but its not all bad.

The roles that Reese Witherspoon and Paul Rudd plays are great, and especially the way the audience really can believe that they are two troubled human beings, dealing with each their own problems. The roles played by Owen Wilson is also great, he is great at pretending (or so I hope, he does) to be a shallow, no brain stud, he often have this element in his roles and it works great. I had hoped that Jack Nicholson had a larger role then what he had, I simply loved him in As good as it gets, in this he has a smaller role but he is still good, I especially love the last scene with him and the face he makes (that's priceless).

I did like the film, but I could have wanted some more fun and more "action" on the way, it takes time in developing and showing us the characters and usually that's not a bad thing, but when you expect comedy all the way, then it takes to long to get acquainted.

This film was very boring, I like all the actors and am a big fan of Paul Rudd and really was looking forward to seeing this film and so was my girlfriend.

We were so disappointed,the whole story just didn't seem to have any point to it, well yes, there was a point but it took so long to get it across we lost interest,The actors did a their part okay, but the whole thing just didn't take off.

I was hoping to get a comedy but all we got was a sleeping pill. All The funny parts were all in the trailer so we felt cheated.

Don't waste your time or money with this film.

Go out for a pizza instead!

Was looking for a rom com and stumbled across this gem. Yes, it is predictable, yet with a strong morale core. All the famous actors do a great job and it is fascinating watching them work. I like the way the director also uses the camera to make the most of his stars. Very entertaining, easy to watch, uplifting, and a great ending. Just what I want in a light rom com.

review_title: Don't go by the low rating!
review_detailed_main: How do you know is a 2010 American romantic comedy film starring Owen Wilson, Paul Rudd, Reese Witherspoon and Jack Nicholson. Can't understand the low rating it was not that bad. A good romantic light hearted movie to watch. Great acting, the storyline was not to bad , it had me entertained and i thoroughly enjoyed it. I would class the movie more of a romance than a comedy. Don't be fooled by the low rating and watch it. Currently streaming on Netflix right now.
How do you put so many brilliant actors/comedians in one movie and still fail to make it funny or interesting?

review_title: Such pleasant stars. What could possibly go wrong?
review_detailed_main:
It looked so promising. Reese Witherspoon, Paul Rudd, and Owen Wilson are all pros at rom com (although Wilson always plays himself, which is no huge achievement), and yet there was precious little comedy and no romance. Sure, off-screen humping, but no chemistry in any of the pairings. The only relationship even slightly interesting was the father-son relationship. On top of that, the three main characters are beyond a mess, without even the excuse of being very young and inexperienced in relationships. I'm not sure I've ever seen three characters so uncomfortable in their own skin. There IS such a thing as apologizing too much.

The oddest thing about this film is the delivery of lines. It's clearly deliberate, since all the characters are doing it. By "it" I mean they deliver their lines haltingly, as if they're seeing the script for the first time. Or as if the actors can't quite believe what they're being made to say. It reminds me of a stand-up comic who hasn't yet learned the timing of a joke. Or worse, gets the punch line wrong and then tries to fix it. It's embarrassing. Witherspoon and Rudd are so much better than this and were so even 10 years ago when the film came out.

The clincher is that every moment of the film is predictable. Bleh.

review_title: How Do You Know? We Know **1/2
How Do You Know that a $100 million dollar budget has been completely wasted? This movie, right here.
How Do You Know--When Not to Spend $11.00 for a Movie?
review_detailed_main:
The answer to my question in the summary is to read my review. Stay home and save the money. As matter of fact when it comes out on DVD or On Demand--save the money too. It was just that bad! You ask why I gave it a 2 in a rating. Simple, I was able to sleep for about a good hour during the movie. The other good thing was that my wife was next to me, also nodding off.

I am sorry to do this. I really enjoy Reese, Owen and Jack, however, the movie did not click. The acting was below par, the writing terrible and the settings very poorly structured.

Seems to me that Hollywood should have known better and not released this movie.

Meanwhile, when does The King's Speech coming to Jersey?

As for a romantic comedy, then "How Do You Know" was fairly slow and lacked some of that special ingredient to make it stand out from the many, many others in the same genre.

Sure the movie had an impressive list of cast, and there was some good chemistry between Reese Witherspoon (playing Lisa) and Paul Rudd (playing George). And they worked well together on the screen. Also Owen Wilson (playing Matty) was well cast for that particular role. Most impressively was seeing Jack Nicholson (playing Charles) in this movie, he truly is a diverse actor.

The story in "How Do You Know" is basically right out of the romantic comedy cookbook; two people meet and eventually get to find love, and of course need to get through the obstacles along the way. Pretty textbook material there, so don't expect any major new-thinking in the movie. But still, the story was enjoyable, though at times very slow moving.

There are other romantic comedies that have more meat on it, so to speak. But for fans of Reese Witherspoon, Paul Rudd or Owen Wilson, then this movie is a good addition. I didn't mention Jack Nicholson here, because he is better in other types of movies.

I was entertained throughout the movie, despite the long patches of endless dragging on. However, I can't say that I will be putting the movie on a second time. For me, it just doesn't have that much appeal.

review_title: Not a Typical RomCom, in the Best Way
review_detailed_main:
I bought this movie for $1 at a Family Video 5 years ago. I just watched it tonight. I could almost cry.

Read the other good reviews to hear the really good things about it. The reason I adore it is because Paul Rudd's character is absolutely autistic-coded, whether intentionally or not. I saw myself in him, and it made me so happy to be able to identify with his character.

Like others, rating 10/10 because it doesn't deserve the awful average it has. This one's not going in the Goodwill pile.

review_title: Why are people saying that this movie is wonderful?
review_detailed_main: I watched the movie. Someone here said it was funny, I didn't eve chuckle, except when I read that review. It wasn't romantic, it wasn't actually even enjoyable. I got this from the trivia about the movie: "A huge flop, this only made $7.6 million on its opening weekend." I can see why. What a waste of acting potential. The story was beyond boring and rather ridiculous. I won't ever waste over 2 hours on this one again :)

Despite having a pretty decent core of stars, this movie was a flop. The story really didn't make sense and was not interesting. I also wasn't invested in the "love story" and found Reese's character highly unlikable. I'd pass on this.

review_title: worst rom com I have ever seen

review_detailed_main: The people giving this film 1 and 2 star ratings clearly don't get the film. To say there is no comedy and no chemistry between characters is being incapable of seeing the subtle. The quirky nature of the characters creates a different type of chemistry to the standard romantic comedy production line being produced out of the USA. The comedy is very witty and again has a distinct subtlety to it. If you like the kind of comedy that reaches out of the TV and slaps you across the face this is not the film for you. If you want to watch something that has a quirky, witty and very unique charm then you can't go wrong with this film.

Who among us hasn't spotted a film option on a streamer that's a few years old and thought, "Wow! That's a great cast! How did I not see this?" and started to watch without first checking reviews? Paul Rudd, Reese Witherspoon, Owen Wilson...we get in a few minutes and "oh hey! Kathryn Hahn and Jack Nicholson! We really missed out on what's sure to be a gem! How lucky are we?!?" And then, very slowly, the head scratching begins. "Wait what? What is happening here? Was that scene supposed to be so cringey? And that one, too? Geez Paul Rudd just has no chemistry with Reese Witherspoon. That's a bummer" ...but you continue on, because of that GREAT CAST, right? "Oh OK, I guess Reese is supposed to be with Owen Wilson...nope no, again no chemistry and is Owen's character supposed to be funny? We're used to his charming but flawed routine but he's just repugnant"... That's how the conversation went for another 15-20 minutes before we gave up. I very rarely bail on a movie 20-25 percent in and I almost never write a review for a movie I didn't (couldn't) finish. But I owe it to the fans of these fine actors and the film watching public in general. Unfortunately I probably won't save very many folks with my review because of that GREAT CAST. Shame on James L Brooks - he did ALL of us dirty!

The beginning of the movie (the very beginning) like the first 5 minutes, sets you up to believe that this movie is going somewhere and that it has a strong story line but as the movie progresses - NOTHING. It's absolutely unrealistic, no intrigue, no insightfulness and the ending was empty with way to many loose ends. I love the actors, but this movie is unbefitting of their talents.

Dropped baseball star Witherspoon meets up with business director Rudd who is being investigated by the Justice Dept and a will they / won't they tale ensues. This is complicated by Witherspoon's existing relationship with self obsessed Wilson and Rudd's issues with his company owner father - Nicholson.

There are undoubted some sweet moments and a few funny scenes (mostly from Nicholson), but these are few and far between in this mess of a dramady with so many plot holes. Witherspoon's baseball back story is meaningless, her relationship with Wilson as a completely selfish idiot just doesn't ring true and the legal issue at the heart of the Rudd / Nicholson element just drifts away. The whole thing is improved by the presence of Rudd and Nicholson but overall a tremendous waste of so much talent.

review_title: How do you know this movie sucks?
review_detailed_main:
Easy, it's not funny, it's not romantic and it cost a boat load of money just to get recognizable stars to show up. It neglects this little important thing called a script. How Do You Know manages to be dull, boring and unimportant all at once. Bravo team, not only did you make a box office bomb, but a failure of a film as well. Let's all give each other a well deserved pat on the back.

Jack Nicholson, looking for a pay check, has a small role as Paul Rudd's father. He tries his best to get Rudd out of some legal problems that he may or may not of had a hand in. Reese Witherspoon is a softball player who gets cut from the team, she cries about it and hooks up with baseball player and all around rich guy, Owen Wilson. They aren't right for each other, but they don't know that yet. You know who's right for her? The down on his luck guy, Paul Rudd.

How Do You Know manages to go beat for beat what one would expect and never throws any curveballs. It not only tries to be formulaic, but it tries to be boringly formulaic. Witherspoon, as adorable as she is, does nothing for this thankless role and she has no chemistry with her on screen male partners. Either of them. Owen Wilson and Paul Rudd are in sleep mode here. They feel more comfortable doing what they do best. Rudd belongs with Apatow doing R- rated comedy and Wilson belongs with Anderson making a quirky film that some people love and some people hate. Here they seem like fish out of water.

What makes the whole thing sting even more is that James L. Brooks is behind the lens. You can skip this so called rom com, because it's missing both of those key ingredients, romance and comedy.

review_title: 2 Hour Episode of Friends with NO Funny Bits.......
review_detailed_main:
......thats what i thought of this movie. I like Paul Rud & Owen Wilson but neither of them could save this.

Nicholson did not belong in this movie and watching Reese Weatherspoons scrunched up face for 2 hours was painful.

I cant blame the actors. The story writers and director should be banned from making more films!!!

I gave it a 3 instead of one because Paul Rud is still a class act given the below par script he had to work with.

This was 2 years of my life that i wont be getting back, oops, i mean 2 hours, but it seemed like 2 years when i was watching it.

Avoid this movie!
Actually a quality movie. I really enjoyed it and found it to be funny (but not in a predictable annoying way like most movies).
Why do they make films this bad ,and much too long @ 2hours.
I think the highlight of the film was when the guy from Perfect Strangers (Mark Linn-Baker) showed up. Since when does anyone care about the Nationals enough to include them in a movie?

All these excellent actors, Reese Whiterspoon, Jack Nicholson, Kathryn Hahn, Paul Rudd, ... in a indigestible soapopera! That's criminal ! I hope James L. Brooks don't make any other movie after that because he's an incompetent director

review_title: Maybe I didn't get it, but this sucked.
review_detailed_main:
This is the worst movie I've seen in a while. I will stop short of calling it terrible though and are willing to concede that maybe I just didn't get what the director was trying to do.

Were he/she trying to focus on realistic characters? If so, then it's a huge failure. Owen Wilson was funny in parts but the other guy would never get the girl in real life due to his lack of balls and boring personality.

I'm all for originality and taking risks so I've given it a 3/10. My advice to the director would be: "Live, learn and never try anything like this again." And to the Actors: "Read the script properly and ignore the money (I used to have respect for Jack Nicholson and Reece Witherspoon) because being associated with this drivel detracts from the good work you've done in the past and limits you're future prospects."

review_title: I CREATED THIS ACCOUNT JUST TO RATE THIS MOVIE
review_detailed_main:
This is my first ever rating on IMDB. Because I really enjoyed this film. Its so funny and special. It feels like good old 90s movies with true meaning.

Look Im not an expert in rating movies.. but I really enjoyed this one and Im soooo glad that I clicked on it on netflix. This will definitely be watched again. Unfair rate. Im not going to trust rating score anymore.. specially not here on IMDB. This was totally unexpected.

Not sure where to begin. I didn't hate it, but it was slow and boring. To be honest I fell a sleep and missed the ending, so I feel like I can't really be fair. Anyway I didn't like any of the actors in any of their parts. Owen Wilson as the arrogant "ladies man"... just didn't worked at all, that was actually horrible. I've always liked Paul Rudd, so it saddens me to see him in something like this. Obviously I haven't seen all of his work, but this was definitely in the bad part. Always Reese Witherspoon isn't a great fit either, I like her a lot. But just like Paul Rudd, she just shouldn't have been casted at all.

The main plot is very, very, mediocre and the side stories unfortunately doesn't add a lot of excitement either. So all in all, just not good.

There's a lot of problems with this movie. Number one - it's boring.

Let's start with the characters. Even though they are, for the most part, encountering the most dramatic moments in their lives, they do not change in any way-shape-form. This might be because they were originally drafted as shapeless and formless. They might as well have no names, just t-shirt pronouncing them: "Optimistic Guy", "Positive Girl", "Meglomaniac Manchild", "Narcissistic Dad".

Two of the characters - Lisa (Witherspoon) and Matty (Wilson) are world-class athletes. This defines them. But we seem them at their games for a total of 4 minutes of screen time. They might as well be Famous Writers or Astronauts (oops, never mind, James L Brooks already used those tags).

The other thing(s) that made this movie dulllll: our 2 Oscar winners. Yep - Jack and Reese phone this one in. From planet Ambien. Cripes, do they know they are in a movie? What kind of direction did they get? "Reese - you're sad", "Jack, you're mad." Wilson and Rudd, a couple of guys with good comic timing, try to bring some energy to their scenes. But Witherspoon doesn't have an improv gene in her entire body, and she thuddily plays of Rudd/Wilson here just like she dry-as-sand played off Vince Vaughn in "Four Christmases".

Back to script - you may care how it turns out for nice fella George (Rudd) and be mildly interested in total-stranger Lisa, but you probably won't give a crap how it turns out for the other 2 central characters who are recycled Flap Hortons (Jeff Daniel's character from Brooks' very fine "Terms of Endearment").

I won't bother with the worn dialog, the swelling score, and the invasive camera-work.

review_title: Nicholson is the king...however not in this!!
review_detailed_main: Nicholson, Rudd and Witherspoon pulled me into this flick as i thought it was sure to be a barn burner of a time however ended up only fizzling like a burnt out matchstick. I actually was nodding off during several parts of this and really only had a 'wow' moment when i thought Nicholson had fathered one of the cast's babies during one of the segments. That Wow moment was brief, unfortunately the movie wasn't. Reese Witherspoon is simply gorgeous and in this she portrays Lisa an out of work baseball player who gets involved within a love triangle between her and the very caring corporate guy George (Paul Rudd) and her on and off professional baseball player boyfriend Matty (Owen Wilson) who seems to only worship himself although never seeming to be wanting to let Lisa go. the bad guy screws up once to many times and the good guy George....It doesn't take a crash course in brain surgery to know the outcome of this flick. this script is not one for surprises or comedy or drama .... Nicholson who portrays George's father in this has worked with director James Brooks a few other times with brilliant results such as As Good As It Gets, Terms Of Endearment all comedies about life but unfortunately this time round they couldn't resurrect the dead!

review_title: How do you know when to laugh?
review_detailed_main: How do you know when to laugh? I never was able to figure that out in this movie that awkwardly and haltingly opens with a flashback on the young Witherspoon character's life in little league and then continues, at best, at a snail's pace. I also couldn't figure out why Brooks would assemble a cast of fine comedic actors and then put them in a film with a script so lacking in real humor. To the extent that this film was watchable, credit absolutely goes to the cast, who desperately tried to bring this snore-fest to life. Credit also goes to the cinematographer, who shot a beautiful film. Not even worth the price of the rental, I'm afraid.

review_title: One of the most notorious cinematic bombs... for all the worst reasons!
review_detailed_main:
HOW DO YOU KNOW is a movie with a notorious reputation. After all, is the last movie for both Jack Nicholson and director James L. Brooks, despite in Italy was released in theaters it's never aired on TV, it's considered by box-office numbers and critics a bomb considering the huge budget (earning $48,000,000 against a $120,000,000 budget) and most of the reviews here are scathing. Well, last July I finally saw it and I could see why it has such a reputation. I even regret it to having spent two hours of my life watching it.

Lisa Jorgenson (Reese Witherspoon) is a young woman in the local softball team that is living a good life on her own and occasionally dates baseball player Matty Wilson (Owen Wilson). In the meanwhile George Madison (Paul Rudd) is working in his dad Charles's (Nicholson) company dealing with some money flushing. Soon after Lisa loses her position on the team and George is framed by the government without having idea why and on top of that, he is left by his girlfriend and she promises to return to him only after his problems will be resolved. Lisa and George will have some dates and mostly end disastrously and then George makes a deal with his father: if he won't manage to win Lisa's love he'll do jail time for his father but if he'll win Lisa's love Charles has to do jail time for his son. After a discussion, Lisa finally goes with George: Charles smiles but soon the smile fades because jail awaits him.

So why the movie is terrible? Because it's embarrassing for its stars, full of disconnected moments and just awkward. Probably the stars didn't even tried with the poor material given, they knew they were in a bad movie and just followed the director's instructions. As for Nicholson, he did his best with the poor material and he's the only one who went out unscathed considering the mess.

The characters don't even look like real people. Since the beginning George is seen like a doofus that has the job only because of his dad, starts to behave whinily when his girlfriend dumps him, it's clueless enough to ruin his first dinner with Lisa and nearly risks to be ran over by a car when he is crossing the street. I mean, can you relate to such a character? Not in the least. In fact, if you run across such a guy on the street you'll likely flee. Matty didn't fared much better because he looked like a slob that loved to talk to Lisa about his many one-night stands and only at half-way in the movie he finally declares his love for Lisa and wanting of settling down with her... it makes you seriously wonder if he was that interested with her in the first place. George's father was probably the only character to which I could remotely relate and when this happens with a supporting character billed as a guest star in the credits, you know you are in trouble. What I liked about Nicholson's character is that he was doing his best for helping his son tho after some time he reveals to having done the dirty work for which George is investigated, and he did some fine metaphores.

Overall, not only one of Jack Nicholson's worst movies but also for the other stars for all the aforementioned reasons. The more it progressed the more I cringed, felt in pain and couldn't wait it was over. My score of 3 is for the nice sets, colorful cinematography and Nicholson's performance because after this bomb he did the best thing to call it quits, it wasn't up to his talents.

Jack, thanks for all the great movies you gave us in the past that serve for a reminder of your excellence.

review_title: Pretty good, some smart writing and excellent performances
review_detailed_main: Paul Rudd is adorable and the rest of the cast is solid. I was happily surprised that this movie was sweet and at times very thoughtful. Give it a chance.

The only reason I gave it 3 stars was because of the cast, these actors were completely wasted in this movie. The entire cast are known for their comedy yet there was a weak script that didn't show off these talents. Story line was totally predictable and could have been told in under thirty minutes. Needless to say it was extremely long, very drawn out and downright boring. I am embarrassed to admit that I wasted my time and watched the entire movie up until the end - I just kept hoping it would improve, but unfortunately it never did and then when I eventually got there the end was boring and weak.

There is no chemistry in this movie. You could dump the reel of celluloid in a bucket of acid, and there would still be no chemistry. I didn't expect a decent performance out of Owen Wilson, and he didn't disappoint.

I did expect Reese Witherspoon and Paul Rudd to make this a worthwhile movie, but the incredibly awkward dialog and failure of direction made this movie unbearable to watch.

All the players in this film have merit in their own right, but the scriptwriting is horrendous. I mean, who doesn't like Paul Rudd. He is probably the only thing that makes this mildly salvageable. Such a forgettable film otherwise.

review_title: Goodbye Jack, sorry it had to end this way.
review_detailed_main:
As a lifelong fan of Jack Nicholson, I sought this out because it appears to be his final movie. What a sad farewell to possibly our greatest ever actor. He does nothing wrong with the little he's given, and it's so nice to see him onscreen, but my, what a sorry excuse for a movie. Reese Witherspoon, a pretty lady, spends a lot of her time wearing the ugliest shorts I've ever seen. This is emblematic of the movie - take some good ingredients and make them unappealing.

A story that is barely there, meandering like a confused senior in a department store. Incredibly slack editing - two hours?? Ye Gods, this could have lost 40 minutes and still seemed like a slog. Scenes go on, and on, and on, Rudd and Witherspoon exchanging dialogue that is as sharp and witty as the list of ingredients on a soup packet. Special mention for the obnoxious performance of Owen Wilson - a character that is supposed to be shallow, I get it, but played with smug disdain by an actor who almost seems to have one hand out for his cheque throughout.

So goodbye Jack, thanks for Chinatown, thanks for Cuckoo's Nest, thanks for all of those great moments. We forgive you the choices you made to bulk out your bank balance so you could afford to make The Crossing Guard and Blood and Wine. We even forgive you for this aberration.

I just don't understand how such a great cast can waste their time on such a shallow movie. Owen Wilson is great but the story line is boring and there's nothing here in terms of emotion and making me care about the characters or how the movie ends. If you want to see the funny parts just watch the trailer. There's no more than what's on the trailer, folks. I was really looking forward to a fun romantic comedy based on the trailer but was so let down. You'd think a movie with Jack Nicholson, Owen Wilson, Reese Wetherspoon, and some other well knowns would deliver. Boy, was I wrong. Did these actors make this movie because they needed some extra spending cash. Their own hearts just didn't seem to be in it.

review_title: A smart and fun dark romantic comedy
How do you know it's rubbish?
Really wanted to like this but....
review_detailed_main:
Maybe it was, as someone pointed out, that the trailers for this movie made it look like it was a hilarious comedy. Maybe I was not in the mood for a romantic comedy that I had to think about. Whatever the reason, the cast alone made me want to enjoy this movie, however, I just could not. The dialog, I thought, was weird. An example of my perception of some of the dialog: He: I need to talk to you. Did you think I thought this? She: No, I thought you were thinking this. He: What? She: What? I've got to go. He: No, I really want to know what you think. She: I don't know. Nevermind. I've got to go, but I do really want to talk to you.

It just seemed like a lot of babbling all the time. In one of the special features, Brooks says he researched female athletes for a year so that he could make a movie about a female athlete as the main character. Then he admits softball took up about 5 minutes of the movie?!? Of all the characters, I like Owen Wilson's the best. He was kind of a lovable scamp except when he wasn't. Paul Rudd is always great and seemed to make the best of the zany dialog. Reese is just fun to watch but I found myself frustrated that a character that was seemingly as bright as she was supposed to be was constantly speaking drivel. Jack was, well, Jack. I too liked the character of the secretary/assistant and she brought a real down-to-earth feeling to an otherwise other-worldly movie. But even she seemed to be looking on in amazement during some of the scenes as these characters went on about nothing.

I got quite a few laughs out of this movie. I was looking for a RomCom and this seemed to foot the bill. But it turns out to be silly and unrealistic which was worthy of a few laughs. But soon I came to understand it was really an excuse to pull in as many known actors as possible and the script really didn't matter. The second level of laughs came from the absurdity of the whole movie and that it was clearly planned and executed to be just that. It's a bit on the slapstick side.

The dialog is so off-normal that it is hard to follow but then I don't think this movie is about a story, just larger-than-life characters.

We watch an episode of Monk each Friday at our house for our pizza and movie night. It was really funny to see Tony Shalhoub as the therapist instead of the client.

I went into this movie with no expectations. I had never even heard of it. But what I got was a movie with a script that probably needed to be given a couple more drafts. It was a mess. Maybe it made sense in the screenwriter's head but most of the time a movie needs a fuller perspective from lots of people. The dialogue was artificial. So were a lof ot the situations. I made it 50 minutes in and I just didn't care anymore. This felt like an alien studied human behavior and then made their best attempt at how humans interact.

It's been some time since Jack Nicholsen and James Brooks were showered with Oscars for Terms of Endearment along with Shirley Mclaine and Debra Winger. Nicholsen has grown a pot belly from too many studio lunches and drinks. Under the thick glasses, you would barely recognize the slim youthful lead who rushed to countless locations of Roger Corman films made with a home movie budget crew. While midlife crisis and divorce themed Endearment, How do You Know reworks it to the point of alzeheimer's disease. It is twice as long as it needs to be with each scene and character exploring two sides of each decision in the story. Will stock broker Nichosen fire son Rudd or won't he? Will Witherspoon marry millionaire Wilson or choose Rudd, who we can see she always likes better from the start? Each small scene the characters ask will I say this or won't I? Will pregnant secretary O'Toole tell Rudd the office secrets or won't she? Will most people want to stick it out until the end of the film? Well, you probably won't. I must add that for such a lengthy romantic comedy, it's strange Witherspoon is not kissed at all except off camera by Owen Wilson.
It's a good movie, not a pink-cloudy-funny kind. I really enjoyed it. Just one thing; if I'd ever choose between Owen Wilson and Paul Rudd I'd choose a threesome. I mean c'mon!!! :D

I don't expect much from romantic comedies... Ever... It's not my favorite genre and the only one I really liked was When Harry met Sally. But I'm not too demanding either when it comes to them. For example, I found Life as we know it to be sweet and interesting. But this one is beyond lame. And not because I found the storyline unusually boring or bad for this type of movie. My problem was with actors and their acting. If it were no A-cast movie, it would be o.k., but I just couldn't believe that I've been watching Reese, Jack and Paul struggle for 2 hours like zombies. Reese, usually very charming and sweet was boring and annoying, not to say more. Jack, usually - we know what's he usually, was sleepwalking (dreaming that he's Al Pacino). Paul was the brightest spot, but waaaaay below his level. Not that I'm a fan of him, but I usually don't have problem with him as I have with Owen Wilson. And I won't comment him... Anyway, they didn't connect for 2 hours and I guess you really need to have talent to do this! As if they all played their roles in front of a mirror, someone taped it and put it together. As if it was their first rehearsal of a play - just sitting and reading the text out loud.

review_title: Don't judge a book by its cover
review_detailed_main:
Grandma was right, judging by this cast this show seems outstanding!

It was slow, I nodded off twice only to awaken to find it was still not over yet. Poorly written and delivered dialog that sounded more like a first reading than a seasoned actor droned on and on and on.......

The ONLY memorable funny line was so crass and pointless I don't even want to repeat it. Reese Witherspoon seemed cold and confused about what she was suppose to do, Owen Wilson sounded like he was waiting for someone to feed him a line or cue him the whole time. Paul Rudd, stared most of the movie like a moron without a clue. Jack Nicholson looked and acted so badly I though it HAD to be someone else.

A totally unexpected joy to watch was Kathryn Hahn. Although at times compared to the others her OVER THE TOP acting was on the edge of crazy her tone made it hysterical and I really enjoyed her mood swings and silly attitude.....she showed up with her A game....the only thing I really appreciated it.....

not funny, not romantic, not well so bury it with Ishtar and call it a lesson in what not to do.....

review_title: A good reminder that even successful stars take terrible roles!
review_detailed_main:
Well, I feel better about myself and my mistakes in life, after watching a film that makes you go, "Why on earth did these highly successful actors agree to do this movie???" I mean, you'd think with a lineup of names like this, it couldn't possibly be bad.

Strangely, it isn't as much "bad" as it is... confusing? What is going on in this movie? The acting is good, but everything else is just weird. Someone else's review made me laugh out loud -- they said it was so strange and yet they couldn't stop watching. I agree!

The story and script are really quite terrible, but I watched it all the way to the end. I laughed once (Owen Wilson's character reads a note he wrote to Reese's character, and for one brief moment in time, he's funny again!). I spent the rest of the movie asking myself... "Where is this conversation going?" over and over. Puzzling.

I'm honestly not even quite sure what to rate it. I guess I'll give it a 5 since I watched the whole thing and am now commenting on it. Ha!
I do not understand how this went into theaters. This was the most horribly paced, edited, written, acted, and scored movies I have ever seen.

I thought it was an excellent blend of comedy, humor and depth of thought. This movie challenged the normal cookie cutter approach to writing and the characters (Rudd's and Witherspoon's) developed a deeper insight into their choices and behavior. I thought the cast was excellent, with Reese Witherspoon giving a performance that I had not seen before from her. Paul Rudd also went into unchartered territory with his very muted but engaging person. Jack's performance was his usual staple and very in line with a narcissistic Dad. Owen Wilson's performance was also his energetic self but with more reflection than his previous performances. As stated in other reviews the actress who plays Rudd's assistant was excellent.

review_title: Would still be bad if written by someone else
review_detailed_main: What I mean by that is that this movie is not just suffering in comparison to James L. Brooks' other films. It's pretty bad all on its own. It meanders, it thinks it's cleverer than it is, and mostly I just didn't much care what happened. The only characters I cared about were Owen Wilson's immature but endearing Matty (who, at least, was not made out to be a bad guy; I give the movie props for that), and Paul Rudd's character's pregnant assistant (more of her would have been great, as she was the only one who made him interesting). I felt absolutely no love from what was supposedly the big love story. So, yeah, not making comparisons... but I'm going to go watch As Good As It Gets and forget this wasted two hours :)

review_title: "When Life Kicks You When You're Down"
review_detailed_main:
Boring watch, won't watch again, and can't recommend.

Paul Rudd (especially) and Jack Nicholson are actors I would use as a barometer for movie quality, and even Reese Witherspoon (even though I'm not a big fan) usually is in quality movies, but this is just such a dud.

It's the rom com equivalent to watching paint dry. Everything about it draws enormous attention to what you would expect to be happening and not doing it. Trust me, I understand that subversion of expectation is comedy, but there is a rate of diminishing returns on the repetition and duration of the joke, and if you play with that line, then you're writing a comedy for comedy writers because they are the only ones that are going to look at the movie / life as a punchline, and I don't think that is what they were going for.

There is an underlying theme of patience and adaptability: life will even out even in the roughest of situations, but the movie just sort of stops without even an epilogue, they're just literally and suddenly not there anymore.

I think there is a lot to get out of the movie, if you're strong enough to reach for it: a man who has everything but doesn't give you what you need isn't as good a man who has almost nothing and wants to give you what you need. It's a counter argument to "Nice guys finish last".

Please don't waste your time, go watch anything else Paul Rudd has been in except for the one where he buys a French villa.

At first time I thought it will be a cute romantic comedy, but I was shocked.

I totally misunderstood the point of the movie. Complicated psychological dialogs, uncertain relationships between the characters ..... complete chaos.

Reese is an excellent actress, so I am very sorry that she plays in such a bad movie.

Her character irritates me terribly, her facial expression, speech .... weird.

And the worst thing is that the movie is about two hours long! Two hours of wasted time!!!!

Damn!
An entire movie that's about just playing hard to get. No substantive material. What a waste.

review_title: Yeah... what was the point of this?
