review_detailed_main:
This was all over the place, back and forth, going nowhere and ultimately without an ending. I don't really know what this movie was trying to achieve. It did start out alright, different than I was expecting anyways, with a fun ensemble cast and a storyline that wasn't the usual rom-com crap. And while I'm not usually a fan of Reece Witherspoon I didn't mind her here, she looked beautiful and her storyline surrounding being cut from the National softball team because she was past her prime was at least interesting. I also enjoyed Owen Wilson in his playboy pitcher role, he had some funny lines. It was nice to see Jack Nicholson again too -where the hell has he been lately?

As the movie progressed though it just seemed to stall out, with Reece sporting a perpetually confused expression as she evaluates her life, moving in with 'Matty' moving out again, then entering into a love triangle of sorts with 'George' a cooperate guy in turmoil who she has zero chemistry with, plus he's acting like a lunatic.

There were also many scenes involving catching the bus, why was everyone on the bus? And then the movie just ends without resolving any of the story lines. The credits roll you go huh?? And then think to yourself, what a waste of time. 10/13/14

review_title: All over the place...but it was worth the wait
review_detailed_main:
I really try to NOT read reviews and/or view overall score before I see a movie. I'm glad that I DID NOT read the reviews until after.

It was a bit all over the place, kinda confusing but I wanted to wait till it came to a meaningful ending...whatever that was, and it did.

As you can tell I am not giving anything away in terms of spoilers.

I will say that the part played by Jack Nicholson was absolutely perfect for him. He's annoying at times, but mostly he sucks the life out of movies, and he kinda did here, but he did redeem himself.

The cast was outstanding, I enjoyed each and everyone one of them.

To all those who ripped the movie I get where they are coming from, but I saw this in a totally different aspect than that of them.

I'm on a Reese Witherspoon ride right now, soaking up all her movies, so many more to see.

If you read this BEFORE seeing movie, give it a chance and not be swayed by the negative reviews.

review_title: Terrible Flow and Script given to some Great Actors
review_detailed_main: Love all of the cast but even the greatest actors cant turn Turds into Gold. Tried to watch it twice but couldnt keep my attention long enough unfortunately. There is just something off that i cant put my finger on.

review_title: Miscast or just badly told it is watchable - just.
review_detailed_main:
Romantic comedies have a formula which is usually constructed from a series of set pieces. In some respects the formula can never be bad but more often than not it can't be good either. This film does have an original group of leading characters especially if I include Annie (an excellent redeeming performance from Kathryn Hahn) and a five minute cameo from Al (Lenny Venito) as Annie's baby's father.

For the rest Reese Witherspoon isn't stretched, Owen Wilson plays a pretty pathetic baseball player character, Jack Nicholson is reduced to parody of himself, and Paul Rudd is just, well, too good for this script.

Lisa is a softball player past her sell by date who seems to have ignored who she is for far too many years. Matty is a bit of a superficial ass with no redeeming qualities at all other than giving the film a "star name". George is the butt end of his father's misdemeanours in a company in trouble with the feds.

Lisa has an epiphany she lives to regret after a one night stand with Matty. George's rather vacuous relationship with Terry is placed by the latter "on pause" because he and his family are in deep trouble. And Annie just forgets how pregnant she is in supporting her "boss" George.

Now the film could have gone in any number of directions from here but it kinda doesn't take the most rewarding route. We are however treated to a few set pieces which restore the idea of romance to the cinema via tried and tested means and it is this which redeems it from awfulness and ordinariness.

Not a great romantic comedy but good for a wet afternoon and a tub of ice cream.

When a great movie really works, like director (and television mogul) James L. Brooks's Terms of Endearment or Broadcast News or As Good As It Gets, you don't think of anything but the movie... but when a movie completely misses, you have way too much time to think about how/why it got there...

And Brooks's infamous misfire How Do You Know is way too long... two hours is the length of a cold war thriller while a comedy needs to be 90 minutes, especially a rom-com, and unlike Brooks's other movies with Jack Nicholson... that are quite long but for good reason... this is not a dramedy... although it's bathed in pretentious melodrama, and takes itself way too seriously...

As the neurotic characters explain so much, at one point they're explaining explaining, and that includes championship softball player (ever heard of that?) Reese Witherspoon, being her usual adorably cuddly blonde but without a story, as tiresome as Paul Rudd's nervous stammering confused nice guy or Owen Wilson doing his usual, Owen Wilson impression...

Here Owen's a shallow professional baseball player sleeping with good girl Reese while Rudd, an honest (or oblivious) businessman being set up by Nicholson as his crooked businessman father, becomes smitten with the same cute yet burdened girl that Brooks really wants you to care about, like Helen Hunt or Debra Winger or Holly Hunter... but there's simply no story here, just a lot of taking in circles, and circles and circles.

review_title: How do you know what the story is?
I would ask my money back if I had paid to watch
review_detailed_main:
The film is terribly bad.

It can be easily noticied why the box office wasnt even half the movie budget.

The dialogs are mostly pointless, there is no story development... it does look like two chronicles running side by side with same characters... There is NO CONNECTION between characters.

The plot development is stupid.

This movie is a two hours waste of time.

review_title: 9/10 Best+ Most Thoughtful Romantic Comedy in years. Very laugh-out-loud scenes, too bad some ppl might not get them.
review_detailed_main:
Extremely under-rated film. Great script, very deep and a few very touching scenes. Many funny moments...laugh out loud kind of jokes.

The jokes were so thoughtful, perhaps the reasons the rating is so low is because too many ppl didn't get it. Great acting, many deep meaningful + wise messages in the script. Dont get fooled by the ratings...

I wished more people get to see it.......so deep and touching. Too bad chemistry btw Rudd and Witherspoon could have been a bit better. She was put in a tough spot, and the movie time frame might have been a bit rushed in reality. But Great acting by Owen Wilson...and Hahn was flawless in her acting. Rudd was great as well...everyone was.

If u want a deep, funny, touching and thoughtful film, go watch it.

review_title: Turn it off ..wait is that Reese Whiterspoon?
review_detailed_main:
I like to say I made this just because of how disgusted I feel after watching this boring,romantic? film. I was attracted for the cast initially. The film starts kinda nice but after a while you can see some cringe teen moments and the people acting like 30 something college kids.

The only reason why I gave this one two stars was BC of Reese looking so cute! Stupid,both dialogues and storyline, lame and unreal behaviors,overacted acting,unlikeable main characters etc...

Even OwenWilson and Jack Nicholson were just off. My conclusion a bad film with good actors... it happens.

review_title: Not a Rom/Com but a Ruined Com
review_detailed_main:
I don't think I have seen any recent film with four A list stars that was so bad. There's an old adage that no one can save a bad script. And that was true here because the acting was as bad as the action.

Reese Witherspoon is a female baseball player cut by her squad and unhappy about it. But, having her as a ball player was an irrelevance to the plot, once you found the plot.

She is going with another baseball player,Owen Wilson, in his worst performance, trying to be a selfish, shallow jock.

Reese then meets Paul Rudd, who is in legal trouble over illegal deals by his firm. He also in unhappy. They are made for each other, but Reese doesn't know this and keeps running back to Wilson, even though she knows better.

Nicholson plays a non supporting supporting role and seems very tired, as do all the players. Reese and Rudd could have been on Valium or something the way they floated lethargically through their roles.

In the end you wonder why did you watch this unromantic turkey that displayed no chemistry at all between the players, except whatever chemicals they may have been taking to keep them from walking off the set.

When a writer sits down to write a movie like this, do you think they believe they are writing something good? That would be weird. Because it's so plain to everyone that this movie is BAD. Dumb, unfunny, boring and for some reason really freaking confusing. This movie is a poopoo. A very colorful poopoo, because whoever edited this movie decided to turn up the saturation 50%. It's almost so bad that it IS funny. The writing and direction is so backwards that I was actually having a good chuckle. Fortunately there are some actors who are so fun to watch they can supersede the massive poop movie they are in. They are like a piece of corn in the poop. Even in the midst of poop they are still pretty sweet, Owen Wilson and (kind of) Paul Rudd are the corn in the poop. Own Wilson makes me laugh. Love that guy. It surely doesn't make the movie any better, but there is still some edible material here.

review_title: A Nutshell Review: How Do You Know
review_detailed_main:
Written and directed by James L. Brooks, How Do You Know is a romantic comedy that decided to go on a roundabout manner in presenting its many messages about love and life rather than cutting to the chase, having many indecisive characters figuring just what to do at important milestones, and basically having them stuck there to bloat this close to two hours. It's a little frustrating to watch plenty of whining going all round, and I felt that much can be salvaged if the pace was kept snappy and succinct.

Two narrative threads run through the film, revolving around a growing romantic triangle between the characters of Lisa (Reese Whiterspoon), a baseball player on the national team who discovers that her life thus far has been unceremoniously cut down after it's decided by the head coach that it's time for her to make way for new blood, George (Paul Rudd) the CEO of his father's company who has been charged by the Federal Court for a Sarbanes-Oxley type of fraud that can see him potentially facing jail time, though of no fault of his own other than to assume things are coasting along, and Matty (Owen Wilson) the successful sportsman whom Lisa is dating in an on-off-on manner.

While it may seem like a character study of all three, everyone shares a basic characteristic of being excessively whiny, and at times needy, wanting things to go their way, and requiring listening ears to hear them out. I understand that most are at major crossroads - one not knowing what to do coming out of a sports career her whole life to date, the other facing felony charges through no fault of his own, with the suspicion that his dad (Jack Nicholson) may be responsible for the whole shebang and he's the scapegoat being set up for the fall, coupled with being ostracized by the people he knows, and Wilson's Matty deciding to no longer become the playboy Casanova and go monogamous for Lisa - but observing them go through their mood swings sometimes don't always make for a good comedy.

And too much of something makes this extremely tired to sit through, and it's a painful endurance to the final act where things get pieced together and a semblance of a certain direction Brooks wants to take with this. DOn't get me wrong, I enjoyed each and every nugget of experience and advice that Brooks wanted to dispense through the characters, especially that between Lisa and George where they ultimately learn and share through their conversations, even though Lisa tries hard to keep things platonic, and we the audience know that George secretly desires more. Moments I thought had plenty of substance belonged to the tale about Playdoh - presents becoming meaningful when they come with a morale lifting story - and that involving shutting up to think rather than to engage in verbal barrage that will probably serve more bad than good.

Owen Wilson may be sleepwalking in this role here since he doesn't offer much as the alpha male jock who's none too bright though possessing enough to surprise sporadically, while Reese Whiterspoon probably needed a meatier role than this one, having to play a character gone neurotic when realizing she's out of her own comfort zone like fish out of water. Paul Rudd though continues to grow from strength to strength, showing he has what it takes to shine in serious dramatic moments, laced with that likability of being an everyday Joe that you'll probably root for. However, all three stars get outshone by the presence of Jack Nicholson each time he comes onto the scene, and frankly his last few scenes opposite Paul Rudd was some of the best this film had to offer.

Still, the performance of the cast failed to steer this film out of its self-indulgence, deciding to run on the spot rather than to move the story along. It's one thing dispensing good advice, but it's another if one likes to listen to one's own voice. I would like to love this film as I did James L. Brooks' Spanglish, but alas it went on aimlessly for far too long and wasn't able to salvage the damage done.

At first I didn't understand at all , I was expecting romantic comedy but further on in the movie I started really loving it! So much scene's I recognized from my own life :-). It made me feel "at home in this world" kind of movie!!

review_title: "I care about you so much I'm going to TRY cutting out the anonymous sex...."
review_detailed_main:
"How Do You Know" is a very unromantic romance...and this is probably THE reason why it failed so miserably at the box office. While it may or may not have contributed, director James L. Brooks and Jack Nicholson simply stopped making films after this bomb. And, in terms of bombs...this was a big one...earning back about $48,000,000 with a budget of $120,000,000!

When the story begins, Lisa (Reese Witherspoon) is on the US women's softball team, dating a pro baseball player (Owen Wilson), and living a good life. As for George (Paul Rudd), he is making a ton of money, has a pretty long-term girlfriend, and is working for his father (Jack Nicholson). However, over a very short time, Lisa loses her position on the team, George is under indictment by the government and has no idea why, and his 'loving girlfriend' leaves him and promises to return AFTER his problems have resolved themselves...in other words, she dumped him. Can these two hurt people, George and Lisa, find each other and make something out of it?

So why do I think the movie tanked? Well because although it was a romance, there was a lot of content which was about as romantic as a case of the clap! During most of the film, Lisa was living with and/or dating the ballplayer...a man simply incapable of loving anyone. He appeared to be a sex addict and talked about his many, many, many one-night stands. Then, inexplicably, he says he's interested in settling down with Lisa...and utters the most unromantic line I can recall...and it's in the summary above. Wow...it really makes you wonder about Hollywood and its views on fidelity and relationships...perhaps to these folks that IS being romantic. He just seemed like a pig and she seemed pathetic for staying with him.

Another problem with the film is that a ton of money was spent on the film...too much. Had it been a movie that was special effects intensive, like a Star Wars movie, you could say "well, I see why the movie cost so much to make"...but here you wonder HOW $120,000,000 was spent on the film and why it took five years to complete! I think this insane spending is evident in the script, as so many story elements seem ill-placed...such as the story about George's father (Jack Nicholson) and the ball playing boyfriend. Without this, just Rudd and Witherspoon forming a relationship, it would have worked...as BOTH were very likable and did great work here. But the irrelevant supporting stories often just got in the way. What also got in the way was the very explicit song that Rudd kept singing as well as it playing at the end...a song by Barry White that really ISN'T about romance at all...just screwing!

Overall, a film worth seeing but also a film with many flaws. Not a terrible film but with this cast and crew, it should have been so much better.

My husband and I watch a lot of movies.

We both like Reese Witherspoon so we expected to like "How Do You Know."

Unfortunately, the plot wasn't interesting; the acting mediocre, Ms. Witherspoon did not look like her normal svelte self, and we were just plain bored. There was no chemistry between the actors and we thought Owen Wilson's character was cheesy altogether.

My husband asked me about 1/2 way through if I even wanted to finish the movie; it was that disappointing.

We did finish it, hoping it would get better or at least have a redeeming message at the end, but it did neither.

We can't recommend this movie - to anyone!

Or in that case: I should have. I was warned, but I ignored the negative attention the movie got. I wanted to see for myself. And Jack Nicholson couldn't be that bad, now could it? Well it's not Jack who ruins the movie. Owen "Playboy" Wilsons character is completely ridiculous and sadly not funny at all.

Paul Rudd whom I like and I think is a funny comedian, is reduced to puppy eyes and dialogue that must have hurt bad, when he was trying to say it. Then again they all need money. Watching Reese W. you might wonder why she is considered a good actress. But she is. Just not in this one. The tone is completely wrong, there is almost no comedy, the romantic "value" (if you can call it that) is even dismissed by women who watch it and the kitsch factor reaches "I want to puke" levels (with both genders).

With so much talent at hand, you never would have guessed they could've gone completely wrong. Well ... they did. So that is actually an achievement in itself.

You would think that a film with such a cast,like Reese Witherspoon, Paul Rudd, Owen Wilson, and Jack Nicholson, that this film could not fail. O'h but it did.

This film is not clever, as it tries, and if your sitting through it, you can see how clever it's trying to be, and you feel ashamed sitting through it. Reese Witherhrspoon who is always a joy to watch, but just wasn't here, although there is one scene she does have good dramatic moment, but other than that she is unwatchable this time around. Paul Rudd is alright in a few moments, but just bring the film above itself. Owen Wilson is so unfunny, cause he says almost nothing right a good part of this movie, and it's comes to a point where it's not funny, it's sad. Jack Nicholson does an extreme amount of overacting, and the way he talks, is like he has something caught in his throat.

review_title: Sure, there were some parts I liked, but overall, just crap

review_detailed_main:
This movie surprised me. I expected it to be just like any other romantic comedy. Instead it was warm, funny and charming.

Everything wasn't polished, perfect and predictable. Some of the dialogue was a little bit awkward. In a good way. Dating in real life is usually a little bit awkward, and not in a super-cute, super-funny, let's-tell-the-grand-kids kind of way most movies portray.

It had a few laughs, but most of all it kept a smile on my face throughout, and left me a little happier than when I first pressed play.

I don't know if it's an eigth or a seven. But as a romantic comedy it's better than most I've seen in recent years.

review_title: Cast is promising, screenplay is horrible
review_detailed_main: Reese Whiterspoon is so above this film! The characters are incredibly boring and their emotions are lacking at best and unbelievable at worst. I have no attachment to any of these characters.
Considering the cast of this film I expected big things - little did I know it was in fact the most dull watch of my entire life. Switched off after 80 minutes, very disappointed.

So many elements of this movie were promising. Paul Rudd, a very handsome man with a talented smile and twinkling eyes, usually faultless comic timing is utterly wasted in this mess. Reese Witherspoon, a respectable actress is one of the most unlikable characters I have witnessed in a lead role for some time. I normally like her performances, but this one was dismal, largely based on her soulless, anaemic, irritating character. Jack Nicholson is secreted in the recesses of the movie, like a slightly infected crevice, festering in the background, his occasional appearances uninspired. Owen Wilson is his typical type-cast self, if less redeemable than usual. Overall, the script will make you want to rip your own ears off rather than suffer through any more of its agonising awkward pauses, acted in strange gestures and facial expressions. The music is what one would expect from a rom-com-esque piece, nothing special. The camera-work was passable by Hollywood standards for almost the entirety, except for a few unnecessary shaky close ups. The story-line was pointless.
You can skip the first hour and still understand the plot, boring movie...

review_title: EWWW Jack Nicholson and Owen Wilson
review_detailed_main:
I like Paul Rudd and Reese Witherspoon and that's why I decided to watch it on Netflix.

Then I saw Owen Wilson. I don't like him based upon what he's done in her personal life, especially with his children.

And 13 minutes in I saw that Jack Nicholson was in it.

I shut it off from there.

review_title: Loved It ... made me laugh and cry
review_detailed_main:
Loved It ... made me laugh and cry several times.

Great writing ... very good acting.

If you are a nice guy ... you will really enjoy this movie.

Liked it so much I wanted to give it a good review. Then I noted many unfavorable reviews. Glad I did not see this before I borrowed the dvd from the library or I might have skipped it!

How Do You Know starring Reese Witherspoon, Paul Rudd and Owen Wilson sees in a James L. Brooks romantic comedy. The screenplay would have been worked better on the stage since the scenes fit the format of separate acts in a play.

The movie is void of any effervescence and doesn't have the forward momentum that holds your interest. Witherspoon is real who used to seemingly light up the room with her mere presence, but is woefully miscast as a female jock. Rudd tries to inject some humor but plays his nice guy act and the material overall isn't funny.

Witherspoon and Rudd deserve to be together in a better movie. Wilson just wants to have fun and could play this role in his sleep. Nicholson acts like he is making a guest appearance on a talk show.

Overall, the dialogue of the film and overall essence somewhat reminds of a soap opera television show or something of a plot wise you would find on Friends. Reese's character just isn't too likable as you start thinking more of the film.

The ending is quite predictable and overall How Do You Know just isn't all that romantic of comedic. Not to mention, this film was a major box office flop with a far too high budget that doesn't add up.

I still love all these actors but wow was the writing awful.

Reece's character made insanely stupid choices that didn't line up with any type of logic. She was also relatively unlikeable imo....

Paul Rudd's character also was very dumb, naive, and SO much of a pushover for being essentially second-in-command at his father's massive company. Paul still manages to always make his characters lovable no matter what!

Jack Nicholson was funny! Not a good guy, but he played it well!

Owen Wilson also played a character typical to him. But also super surface-level. His only personality trait was being a playboy....that she was initially repulsed by then remembered she doesn't judge so is immediately ok with it and wants to date him?!?! So odd.
These are 2 hours of my life I will never get back

About 10 minutes into the film, I instantly found the wall next to my TV more interesting. With such an all-star cast, and being a fan of Witherspoon and Nicholson, I was really wondering what they could come up with. Basically, a newly- fired softball player tries to figure out her life, which is made more complicated when two guys show interest in her. Although Nicholson is as well in character as always, and Witherspoon still plays complicated Lisa with a certain believability, the movie is too much at times. It's not complicated at all. It just feels like the scriptwriters tried to fit in too many plots all at one time, which tends to make the movie really overwhelming. Not to mention the fact that Wilson becomes sometimes overly annoying. I guess every actor has a bad movie, and, for these 4 stars, let's hope it doesn't get any worse then this.

review_title: Horrible screenplay, bad bad story in general
How Can It Not Be Adored By Viewers
review_detailed_main: Needless to say, I am stunned that this movie has been received with anything but glorious praise. It was precisely the type of romance I enjoy (similar to Spanglish). It's not overdone, sappy romance. However, there's plenty of well constructed lines relating to love that will make you think and give you perspective. Owen Wilson is consistently hilarious throughout the film and I haven't enjoyed seeing him on the screen this much since Bottle Rocket. There's a perfect balance of comedy and passion, and this movie works great for both sexes. It's certainly not your typical rom-com, but that's what makes it so brilliant.

review_title: Decisions: how does one know how to make them?
review_detailed_main:
This is a gradually paced dramedy with a woman named Lisa (Reese Witherspoon) at a turning point in her early 30s when she got involved in what she's accustomed to being told is the ideal relationship: good looking partner, who's successful, has the same profession and who could forget is great in the sack. Yet something doesn't feel right, so she still has one foot in one foot out to keep her options open when another man unlike who she's ever been with calls her from an acquaintance for a chance date.

Lisa might get cut from the softball team, which turns her normally confident personality into a sentimental yuppie. The newly met guy is a former businessman named George (Paul Rudd) who's unemployed, soon out of money, girlfriend broke up with him and is being investigated with possible prison time in the future. He's normally a stand up guy that got the short end of the stick and is currently looking for a special gal to listen to him and get to know her as well. Currently everything is fun and new with her current boyfriend who has it all but Lisa is looking for someone who treats her as an individual, as her tentative partner--Matty (Owen Wilson) the playboy pro ball player--is giving a serious relationship a try but he has to break his own self-centered and narcissistic habits that are embedded into his suave and charming ways on the surface.

"How Do You Know" is an overly simplistic and minimalistic movie which is essentially summed up as people interact and "things" happen with a camera to film nearly every minute of it. The TV show "Seinfeld" brought about the premise of "doing nothing" and somehow made it work, though here there's not a bundle of significant events or rewards occurring during the process till the end, which felt like three hours to get there and obvious from the get-go. This is basically a series of free-floating events that happen in a short amount of time and are filmed tediously to give realistic room for growth, though it comes across like it lacks a central direction as it's to the point of being so loose that it's aimless at times. A thinking person's movie? Hardly, as it's stretched thin enough.

Jack Nicholson plays George's (Paul Rudd) manipulative dad with his usual sarcastic self who says exactly what's on his mind. Kathryn Hahn does a charismatic role as Annie: the caring secretary who's full blown pregnant and an emotional volcano ready to erupt. There are funny jokes to lighten the load but some seem out of context as there isn't a grounded focus to place them in. It becomes one giant exercise in indecision between the characters to the point where you want to yell out "just do something already!" This isn't going to be rewarding like "Terms of Endearment," "As Good as It Gets" or even "Spanglish" from James L. Brooks, as those had actual things happening over of a period of reasonable time, with memorable characters doing them and also space to ponder upon in between. "How Do You Know" already by the halfway mark makes you want to check your watch and go back to your own life already.

There is no plot in this movie, honestly you keep waiting for something remotely engaging to happen. I had high expectations due to the actors/actresses involved in this film, I was highly disappointed.

The problem with this film is that it tries so hard to make every scene precious that it never adds up to anything. "I laughed, I cried" is the clichéd response a good romantic comedy is looking for, but it can't aim for that every second. You can feel the James L. Brooks telegraphing everything. He used to pull this stuff off effortlessly early in his career with films like Broadcast News and Terms of Endearment, both of which do flirt with melodrama at times, but lately his work feels tired. He's going for a home run with every speech, sad look, close up of an important prop; it really gets on your nerves. He had all the ingredients here, he just laid them on too thick. Nothing is believable, especially the constantly befuddling on again off again relationship between Reese Witherspoon and Owen Wilson. He's such a cad, I don't know why she'd spend more than 10 minutes with him. And, Paul Rudd's character is such a weak puppy dog, I think she'd feel more pity than charmed. A total mess.

I thought that with a great cast, including the queen of Rom-Coms Reese Witherspoon, it would be an enjoyable movie. Not necessarily a good movie but an entertaining movie that the audience enjoys watching. I was disappointed when this overly long movie did not deliver. Not much happened yet it was dragged out. I think part of this is because there are so many stories going on that are trying to be relevant to one another, but fall short. Also, the dialogue was weird and forced. Some of the communication exchanged was awkward or I just did not get it. I think it was supposed to be funny, but it just wasn't.

I would not watch again.

review_title: Awful! Wish I could get those 2 hours back!
review_detailed_main:
I actually joined IMDb to write about how bad this movie is! I recently got this out on DVD (thank goodness I didn't go to the cinema to watch it!) expecting it to be a typical girlie romantic comedy BUT it is nothing of the sort. It is so boring, the script is trying to clever which makes it very confusing, the acting is dreadful and it is not funny one bit. I cannot believe that this movie attracted such an all-star cast. I really like Paul Rudd and Owen Wilson as actors but cannot understand why they agreed this movie. You never get to know the characters properly and there is no chemistry between Reese's character and the 2 male love interests.

Please please don't waste your time watching this movie.

It is one of the worst movies I have ever seen and I am very disappointed that I never switched it off!

I don't know what is wrong with so many people!? My husband and I thought this was one of the best movies we have seen in a very long time! The dialog was excellent, the actors were excellent, the story was excellent! This movie was totally enjoyable. You do have to pay attention and you do have to think some when watching this movie. Maybe that was why so many people gave this wonderful movie a low rating :o( Paul Rudd is now one of my new favorite actors. Reese Witherspoon continues to be one of my favorites. Jack Nicholson was superb, as always. Owen Wilson was....well, he was classic Owen Wilson! Bravo, James L. Brooks!

review_title: Odd waste of a Rom-com, you KNOW it's a miss
review_detailed_main:
From the title, to the cast, to the characters, this film is totally lacking and lame. The Rom-com is trying to be smart, with mind boring dialog, and suffers from a real vital lack of charisma and likable characters. There is little chemistry and content and so confuses and irritates rather than entertain and provide face softening smiles. From a director with a mixed CV, you can almost see into the thinking for elements being the way they are (looking at past films) but the Rom-com element here is lacking both romance and comedy.

Witherspoon is annoying, Rudd is a Rom-com whore, Owen Wilson is his usual effortless self, and Nickelson just looks ill. Surely a better script and direction could have made something more bearable than this. The other fact that the lead lady is a retiring baseball player, dating another player, will also be lost on non Americans.

This was an awkward movie with confusing dialogue and a complete lack of chemistry between the main characters. That's surprising considering the star studded cast. Lisa was a total flake who lacked any depth to her character and both her love interests lacked desirable characteristics. I don't know what she saw in either one of them, and that saddens because usually Paul Rudd brings it in this type of role. But this time he was just awkward and self depricating but not in the adorable way that he is known for. Owen Wilson was shallow and pretty despicable in his own right. Nicholson is a moral cess pool and but he plays that character as well as anybody. In the end don't waste your time!

There is nothing sadder in moviedom than a comedy that is not funny. This movie is supposedly a farce but its execution is completely flat. Reese Witherspoon is a great actress but not in this movie. Jack Nicholson plays a caricature of his screen persona. Paul Rudd is not funny. This movie may have worked better if Owen Wilson had played Paul Rudd's character. This movie needed a Steve Martin or a Chevy Chase or maybe a Cary Grant. Dan Ackroyd may have helped. There are so many things wrong with this movie. This could be Reese Witherspoon's worst movie. Maybe it's the insipid script, the uninspiring story, the miscasting, the overall banality of the production. Whatever it was, it all contributed to producing a movie that is flat, dull, pretentious and mediocre. To the movie's credit, the ending is okay but that's not saying much when compared to its utterly innocuous start. The strongest performance is that of Owen Wilson's and even here the performance is uneven as the the character waivers between fits of immaturity and attempts to act like a responsible grown up. That it is Mr. Wilson who is called upon to provide some actual drama exemplifies the triteness of the story and the uninspired quality of the performances. The movie is purportedly a comedy but it generates no laughs. No amount of pouting by Ms. Witherspoon could rescue this movie. Although lovely and charming as usual, she cannot overcome a weak script. The scenes with Paul Rudd and Jack Nicholson are devoid of anything that even remotely approaches comedy, or drama for that matter. Interestingly, Jim Bouton has a small role in this movie.

It's not often that I find a rom-com from the 00s or early 2010s that I don't like. They're dependable. Occasionally, however, I find one that I've never even heard of before - How Do You Know is just a film.

I'm literally still watching as I write this - it has been forever. Why is this film so long? I have no idea what's happening most of the time; it's like they built a load of robots to look like well known actors and then asked an AI to write a script for them.

It somehow feels both hyper realistic and like a fever dream...and yet I watched all 120 ball achingly long minutes of it. Truly astounding.

I don't rate movies but I use IMDb a lot before deciding to watch a movie. This is my first review because the injustice here was too much for me to bear. I like movies, so will give anything with a 6 or higher a shot. For the most part, the ratings on here are pretty good, not always (I triangulate with a few other sites before committing to a movie). Well this one was WAY OFF. I am glad I did not let the ratings and reviews dissuade me, because this is a great movie.

If you like Paul Rudd (I am a big fan), don't mind Reese (I like her even more now), like Owen Wilson (yep), love Jack (who doesn't?) and loved Terms of Endearment and As Good as it Gets, you will NOT REGRET watching this movie. Enjoy.

review_title: You'll know when you see it.

review_detailed_main: There are movies that make you wonder "why on earth did they do that movie". Awful plot, poor performances. I formed this view before the 30' of the movie and went all the way to see how bad it could really be. Still, i wasted my time..
Far too long for a film of it's kind but Reece Witherspoon is as endearing as ever.

Jack, Reese and Paul: what are these brilliant actors doing caught up in this incoherent mess? Only Owen seems to fit in cos he's best in spoofs and unintentional parodies. But the whole thing here is an unintentional nothing. I thought it was going to be a rom com parody, but 15 minutes into it I was disabused of that notion. I gave it another 15 and I didn't persist. It is rare for me to abandon a flick before the end ibut this narratively, dramatically and cinematically incoherent mess was just too excruciating to put up with.

And the poor said brilliant actors kinda seemed to give up from the start. None of them, not even the great Nicholson, seemed to work with any conviction and looked a tad embarrassed to be "doing their scenes". God awful mess.

One star cos I can't post without it.

review_title: Brooks was one small adjustment away from making a good film
review_detailed_main:
¨We are all just one small adjustment away from making our lives work.¨ How do you know when you're in love is one of the questions one of the characters asks in this film. Director James L. Brooks (Terms of Endearment, As Good As it Gets) tries to answer that question in this romantic comedy (although I would actually label it as a dramedy) by creating a love triangle, but he fails at really trying to come up with an honest answer. The answer Matty receives to his question is ¨I know that I'm in love when I put on condoms when I'm with other girls.¨ A very superficial answer, which actually fits with this superficial movie. Brooks has directed really good films in the past, but he really missed his mark this time around. There were a few funny moments, some memorable quotes here and there, but the script (written by Brooks himself) was just too weak and the pace too slow. The first hour was torturous for me, I absolutely hated every character and every situation, but the second half of the film built up to a somewhat satisfying ending and tolerable characters. I was really disappointed with this movie because I know James L. Brooks is a very talented director and he always tries to make original movies, and I also liked the cast in this film, but the script was just too weak and the performances felt really awkward and out of place at times. I like the cast, just not how they worked together in this movie. The only positive thing I can say is that at least Brooks tries to make a different kind of romantic comedy with less clichés than most other romcoms.

The story actually centers around Lisa (Reese Witherspoon), a star softball player who has recently been cut from the National team because she will turn 31 by the time the next Olympics take place. Her life revolved entirely around the sport and now she's at the point of her life where she doesn't know what step to take next. She has always dated athletes and is currently seeing Matty (Owen Wilson), a professional baseball player both on and off the field. Matty is a star who is used to dating a lot of girls but really doesn't know anything about relationships. He is clueless and really doesn't know how to help Lisa, but he does like her a lot and realizes she is different from what he has felt for other girls. Lisa, although hesitant at first, finds comfort in George (Paul Rudd) who loves listening to her and trying to ease her. At first she thinks he's a weirdo, but later their friendship blossoms. George is going through difficult problems himself, but he puts them aside to try to help Lisa, with whom he's fallen in love. George is a businessman who has just been indicted from his father's company. Charles (Jack Nicholson) actually has set up his son to become the target of a federal investigation by falsifying some corporate financial documents. If George takes the blame he will only have to pay a sentence of 2 to 3 years of jail, while Charles would have to face 25 years if his son doesn't ¨help him out¨. Charles is that kind of father who would let his son take the blame, while George is that kind of son who is too nice and honest and way too ethical to belong in the business world.

My major problem with this movie is that the performances felt too forced at times. I didn't like Reese Witherspoon in this movie, she was selfish and mean, and really didn't deserve someone like George who is just way too much of a nice guy. There wasn't much chemistry between neither of the relationships (Matty-Lisa or Lisa-George). The second half of the film picks up a little and Lisa seems to become nicer, but she really doesn't seem interested in George's problems which are really much larger than hers. All she has to deal with is retirement from softball, but that is really all she cared for anyways. George doesn't seem to mind however, all he likes to do is stare at her. The funniest character in this movie is George's secretary, Annie (played by Kathryn Hahn) and she steals each scene she's in. That is a major problem when you have such talented and funny comedians as Jack Nicholson, Paul Rudd, and Owen Wilson. The scene where Annie is giving birth to her child and her boyfriend is proposing to her is one of the best in the movie and the chemistry those two characters have in those three minutes is much stronger than any other one in the film. This distant romance could have used a lot more comedy coming from Owen Wilson and Paul Rudd who should have been given more opportunities to improvise and loosen up.

review_title: A chick flick but great in it's own right
review_detailed_main: I am avid movie goer. I go to the movies about 3xs a month. This is a chic flick There is no other way to describe it. The script is predictable and nothing is extraordinary about it. Boy meets girl. Girl is taken. Girl leaves boyfriend to get with other boy. But it is a good flick. It has funny moments. It isn't slap stick funny like Horrible Bosses. But it is funny. It was a great movie. Very solid. I give it 7 points because it didn't say whatever happened to the dad. All of the performances were believable and excellent. If you are looking for a movie that is different then all the other chic flicks, don't see this movie. But if you are sucker for chic flicks like I am, this movie was great. I loved it. There was just enough depth to make it believable. The character development wasn't the greatest, but there was just enough to satisfy. Overall it was a good movie.

Let's get right to it. Chemistry between the actors; a BIG FAT ZERO! Comedy writing; another ZERO! Directing; sorry Mr. Brooks, another zero! Huge fan of all the main actors and of Mr. Brooks, but this movie goes nowhere slow with no sense of direction. I can't figure out how this missed with all this talent. I guess they all figured that with James L. Brooks' recent success, they may as well sign up. Well, like the title of my review says, don't waste your time. There is maybe, maybe one funny scene in the whole movie. Just so disappointing! I watched this because it was streaming on Netflix as one of their top movies. I can't figure out why. Just horrible.

Claim that this is "too cerebral for some people" is frankly ridiculous. It's a simple plot, not difficult to follow... but not very well written.

I like all three main actors a great deal, but there wasn't much in this material to work with. A lot of lame crude jokes. Attempts at humor that fell flat. There are a couple of places that tug at the heart strings, but other places that one just sort of wades through it.

All three have been involved in far better and much funnier projects. Jack Nicholson's part wasn't so much a character as it was Nicholson being Nicholson. The current 5.6 rating from 276 viewers pretty much says it all. This film by no means deserves either 1 star or 10 star ratings. It's just mediocre fare, take it or leave it.

review_title: We Only Have Ourselves To Blame
review_detailed_main:
As someone who loves these types of meet-cute love stories, this was just bad. And the bail out of a comedy is just...not really funny. In fact, it's awfully dark in nature. This is strange, considering James L. Brooks is a genius when it comes to regulating "The Simpsons" but now...after this abomination, I tend to believe, he's lost complete touch with people (something that made "Terms..." so great).

It could be that it was original material written by him. Maybe he can criticize what makes a great story, but can't hear it from others. First, the characters are bad. Bad in that they are just terrible human beings. Not unlikeable, just dumb plastic idiots, who say things to service the script. Paul Rudd is dumb. He's swinging in every direction and missing every pitch. I'm sure he realizes that his style of comedy doesn't fit every story. It was bad.

Owen Wilson, same as Paul Rudd, it seemed they both didn't understand the type of movie they were in. Grossly mis-casted. He's too dumb looking, and cardboard to be this type of funny. I think with Wes Anderson flicks, it makes sense. Odd-ball and endearing. In this movie, it looks like he stumbled onto a grown-ups table and can't figure his way out.

Reese...not sure her facial mannerisms. She has fallen so far from what I remember her searing performance in "Freeway." Yes, she's older now. But her character throws hissy fits like a child, surrounds herself with positive mantras, and is...just really aggravating. Why would any of the two guys want to be around this is beyond me.

It seems Brooks direction is stilted and hackey. A fall from a stairwell during a phone call is really hackey. Chaplin couldn't even make that bit work.

I am listening to the commentary now...to get some explanation to this pile of thoughts. And it occurred to me that this must be how Brooks sees the modern rom-com society now. A low attention-span idiots movie, done for a money grab. He's not completely wrong (if you've watched recent ones). We only have ourselves to blame.

Checked watch multiple times during this lame attempt at dramaric rom-com. Have never seen a theater more relieved it was over. Direction-less, poor screenplay, awkward dialogue. A stain on every actors career involved.

How Do You Know (2010) -

Despite the fact that my favourite Paul Rudd was in this film, I felt that it was slightly bland and far too light on the comedy. In fact it was a struggle to find the drama too, but I suppose I might concede that the romance was cute.

I did think that it could have been less obvious how the love triangle would go though. The formula was blatant and there really was no competition between George (Paul Rudd) and Matty (Owen Wilson).

Personally, although it was a sweet romance, which did have something to it, because it was set alongside George's potential indictment, I thought that it could have been awesome if the acting had all been played completely straight and more realistically.

It could have gone the other way and been more silly and farcical instead, but more seriously would have been my choice to deliver this particular concept with this script.

Also, I know that it might have been a bit cliched, but I thought that Jack Nicholson, playing Mr. Madison, could have been a bit more tyrannical as George's father. The actors presence suggested that he would deliver something with an edge, but his character just seemed to fizzle out pathetically.

I think that I just felt a bit let down by this film because it wasn't what I had expected. To make a comparison about similarity, 'The Object Of My Affection' (1998) had better delivery than this and I've seen so many films with these stars that are winners, that it was disappointing to see them signed on to something so weak in this production.

review_title: One of the worst, star-studded films in cinematic history
review_detailed_main:
I never write reviews, but I just couldn't let this one slide.. how on earth this made its way into cinemas is well beyond me.

I hesitate to say this film is even cinematic... not a single phase of the movie shifts coherently from scene to scene. The directing and the plot, combined with the shocking script quality, make you feel like you're being thrown between outtakes of 3 entirely different movies.

The downfalls are countless - from a character whose only purpose is to almost reveal the truth in a singular scene, then give birth in their next cameo, to the main character, Witherspoon, whose arc is simply pro sportsman to air headed love-seeker.

There are the rarest of moments where the acting seems genuine, but between them lies a sea of seriously strange scenes packed with absolutely inexplicable turns of phrase - like, their interactions make no sense, it's hard to believe.

Jack Nichols is particularly jarring, as his character's entire purpose is to shout and be hated for it. That's it. I'm not kidding...

Paul Rudd attempts to be a quirky romancer and hits the mark just a handful of times in this lengthy bore of a film.

Don't waste your time. Nothing happens in this movie. There's absolutely zero character development or backstory. You're thrown into a world of 5 or 6 completely vapid characters who exist in 3 or 4 entirely separate stories. I cannot stress enough how out of place every scene feels compared the last.

A 5.6 average on here is beyond generous.

I find this movie very refreshing and charming with good humor and great acting.

If you were looking for just funny entertaining movie, this probably wasn't it. The plot and characters portrayed human emotions and situations in dating relationships well. It gave some good insights and guidelines to the question we ask a lot in dating relationships. "How Do You Know" if this is the person you want to spend the rest of your life?

No cop outs. I'm also figuring out what I want and how to ask for it. It was helpful for me at least.

How do you know if this is the girl or guy you want to spend the rest of life with? Keep asking.

Last night I flipped through Netflix wishing I could find a movie that felt like a hug. This was exactly what I was looking for.

While this movie looks like a rom com on the surface, it is really so much more than that. This movie is about honesty. It's about communication. It's about taking responsibility and making tough choices. It's about loving imperfect people. It's about loving ourselves. It's about trying to be better versions of ourselves for the imperfect people we love. It is witty, funny, smart and endearing. I thought the dialogue was strange but fantastic. My favorite line: I have kept this for a long time as proof that we are all just one small adjustment away from making our lives work.

I read the reviews by several "well known critics," and I sometimes wondered if I had watched the same movie they were writing about. Ok, so they weren't 180 degrees wrong; the Jack Nicholson character did come across as pretty creepy. Perhaps Nicholson is a rare actor who can even get a wry smile from you when the character he's playing in so unlikeable. He does show some "fatherly emotion" on his balcony at the end, and Nicholson does it completely with facial expressions. Critics complained about the pace, but I never noticed a problem there. Of course, I've always adored Reese Witherspoon, so my objectivity might be suspect. Her character is interesting, I thought. What do you do after winning an Olympic gold medal, and you're suddenly "too old" to continue (at least in the mind of the coach)? It's not like fighting cancer, I agree, but it's not exactly an enviable position either. Call it an "early life crisis." Others here have commented on the movie possibly being advertised as a romantic comedy, leaving room for audience disappointment when what they got was different. Ok. I suppose that might be true. I didn't have any particular expectation, so I had no cause for feeling misled. The big surprise for me was the performance of Owen Wilson, an actor I had never really enjoyed or appreciated previously. His character is sooo insensitive, soooo self-centered, sooo thoroughly lacking in self-awareness. Yet, somehow, Wilson makes him a man we accept, even as we disapprove. I think that Wilson deserves more credit than he likely received for this part. There were several memorable scenes in the movie as well, especially when the Kathryn Hahn is in the hospital after delivering her baby. The scene where Wilson's character tries to "lift" Witherspoon's character out of a depressed mood by telling her an outrageous story about a man and a cat is also very funny. I should say something about Paul Rudd as well. His character is very much in keeping with other roles he's played, so he doesn't really get a chance to show us much, but I did see one thing I hadn't noticed about him before. He showed a knack for physical comedy, a skill often seen in actors from the golden years of Hollywood but not practiced so much anymore. In any case, I think you will like this movie quite a bit, unless you're expecting to be laughing for an hour and a half.

I guess you can call "How Do You Know" a rom-com, though the perspective is a bit wider than a standard boy-meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl story (or the reverse).

The film provides a warm and humorous take on all the random things that affect life from one moment to the next and how we attempt to handle them. The protagonists are both subjected to sudden hardships; the softball player Lisa has just been cut from the team and fired CEO George is facing indictment. Both are trying to redefine their lives and climb out of the hole they have just found themselves in.

This film is not the kind that constantly has you on the edge of your seat, but it does connect with you both seamlessly and without effort due to Brooks' solid script and the on the mark acting.

Kudos to Jack Nicholson as George's moral midget (sic) father and Owen Wilson as the playboy who wants a relationship without necessarily sacrificing anything.

So if you want a film that rings true and has you smiling an inward smile of recognition throughout I think you will really enjoy this.

8 out of 10

review_title: Surprisingly fresh and lovely: respectful, sincere, and hopeful.
review_detailed_main:
How many movies today actually promote respect?

James L. Brooks has directed another movie along the lines of As Good as It Gets and Spanglish, which leaves you with that "good feeling," but also a touch of introspection.

This film is clearly what is commonly known as a rom-com. And despite the fact that I am not easily won over by a genre which is often the least feminist or progressive type of film there is, I was charmed.

I was charmed by the fact that Reese Witherspoon wasn't melodramatic, and I am not typically a fan of this individual...in this case, she was perfect. I was charmed by the overall subtleties of friendship and the cross over of aging with maturity and knowing what you want.

But the biggest concept in this film that I liked was the idea that a man could find purpose not in trying to seduce a woman, but in respecting her. That he could find joy in treating her the way she genuinely deserved to be treated. Paul Rudd was phenomenal and believable in his role. Those expressions. Beautiful.

And the sincerity of Owen Wilson's character as he finally made steps towards caring about someone--finding out that he could do that in a positive, non-sweatshirt giving out sort of way (see the movie to understand). Wonderful. We've all dated this guy. It was great.

I also cannot leave out the stunning performance of the (in my opinion) often underrated Kathryn Hahn, who in many ways steals the show in every movie I've seen her in. She's not afraid to be human, and for that, she may never be the glossy celebrity we are so used to, but she's special. As Annie, she really gave the movie that vulnerability it needed.

There were so many moments in this movie that just really lit me up and gave me a deeper understanding of what it is to care about someone else, but not in a way which merely benefits oneself--in a way that is necessary and respectful.

While there were a few flaws, such as the somewhat loosely tied conclusions in regards to Jack Nicholson's role (seriously?!) or our curiosity in regards to what the main character's employment is other than going on dates and moving in and out of Owen Wilson's apartment, overall, this movie had a streak of feminism and genuine sincerity that I absolutely loved enough to write my first movie review. Well done.

I found this movie (that's "film" for all you faux elites) well directed and unusually affecting. There was a real connection to the characters and their process of establishing a relationship. I was surprised by the acting of Reese and Owen. For Reese, I have not seen her every work but it is by far the most well acted. For Owen, it not easy to portray a genuinely vacant playboy - well done. This is definitely not your mass produced romantic comedy. The comedy is a bit low key but effective and helps keep you interested. The romance is subtle, much like the real thing in life. All of this is of course is my very humble opinion but I was very pleasantly surprised.

The dialogue is actually good. It's different than the usual sappy stuff. The sticking point is that it is delivered like the actors are in a stage musical written in the 50's, right down to Witherspoon's character saying "gee whiz!" when seeing a newborn baby and an employee enthusiastically calling Rudd's character "boss" at every chance. It's a weird choice on the director's part, but I decided to just get over it and from then I really enjoyed the humor and the way the plot played out.

This was a good movie. It was divided into parts and each part was well acted. It's a love triangle and I didn't know who I wanted Lisa to end up with until the end - which was good and made it more enjoyable for me. Highly recommend watching it on Netflix!!

I like hokey romantic comedies. I also like quirky and oddball movies. This one filled the bill on both fronts. I honestly don't get why it got such poor reviews. I loved that there wasn't anyone to hate. I loved the lack of real animosity anywhere (even where it was deserved). Maybe that's why so many people panned it. But for me, this was the gentle, loving, happy story I really needed to see in these contentious times. I loved that nothing made me uncomfortable or anxious, but it still kept my interest, made me laugh, and made me feel good.

The love triangle itself was offbeat from what you usually see. I could've seen the heroine ending up with either one or neither one and I'd still have liked the ending. For me, this flick was a win-win all the way around.

Viewers have knocked this movie but frankly they have thought too deeply. Just let the movie flow, enjoy the clever writing and the star cast. Just because you did not enjoy does not mean it deserves a slating!! Very nice little movie!!

Films like these are meant to be entertaining and I was entertained. I love Owen Wilson, Reese Witherspoon, and Paul Rudd. Some reviewers are too critical when it comes to movies, so if you love these actors, the way I do, you will love this film. The only part that I didn't like, was the part at 45 minutes 43 seconds, the moaning by man and woman having intimacy relations. Nothing is shown, just heard. I made a IMDb movie list that has over 955 movie titles that has no junk in them. So far, my IMDb movie list, has over 177,400 views that shows, many people don't want to watch or hear two people going at it, either.

Written 6/5/22.

review_title: J. L. Brooks philosophy assigned to humans relationships.
review_detailed_main: I think this is a great movie. Characters precisely spotted with very well-formed speeches. I would like to point here that, as far as I'm concerned, the four main characters (respectively performed by P. Rudd, R. Witherspoon, J. Nicholson, and O. Wilson) are tightly connected and coherent. They pass meaningful teaching here, however, just some open-minded and sensible spectators got it. Another Brooks masterpiece.

review_title: It's gotta be the title that makes this movie a turn off
review_detailed_main: The writer was great and I think it just may have a slow start. I understand why the writer called it, How do you know. But for the everyday six grade mentality perhaps it doesn't work. When I rate a movie its in line with everyone else. This movie at this point is NOT a 5.4. As far as what this movie really is as far as IMBD goes it is a 7. I loved it. It's a great Romantic comedy and I highly recommended it. Great lessons as well.

review_title: Can't believe I was crying like a baby ....
review_detailed_main: This movie really surprised me. I got sucked in because I have experienced so many times when I doubted myself and where a relationship was going. I also relate to feeling devastated when something happens suddenly that rocks your world and throws you off balance. Jack Nicholson gives a great performance as narcissistic, manipulative father. The movie reminded me a little bit of Breakfast at Tiffany's,... Flighty girl flirts then runs away, is chased, runs away again... and the little black dress she wears at the end. Script excellent and many memorable lines. Not the usual crude, low-brow humor like most movies lately. Felt like a classic like Casablanca. Too bad so many people didn't appreciate it.

review_title: A flowing movie about decision making.
review_detailed_main:
8.5/10.

I watched this based off a review here by sunam007 which got me intrigued.

This movie gave me a similar feeling of being on acid. Do you ever feel like you're watching the perfect movie to tie into your own life at the perfect time? This was one of those movies/moments for me. It was like being a kid at Sunday morning church & it could have been like you & the preacher were at the service alone and he was talking directly to you.

Life is all about decision makings & seeing how those decisions lead you to where you are today. "How Do You Know" captures that as well as I've seen recently in a movie. The characters just seemed to roll with life so well, following a feeling, that ended up leading them to a splendid ending. It was a lesson in intuition, taking chances, going after the girl, wearing your heart on your sleeve, & not being timid.

This was a perfect movie for a guy like me. I'm relatively young, single, thinking about a woman I'd like to be with, & in a transition in my life. This movie talked to me in a way I can't explain all that well. It was late at night, I had a small edible, put my phone down, & gave it all my attention. It was a special moment & I hope that someone can relate to what I'm trying to say here. Give it a shot. It's better than the reviews. You may just learn something & it may just take something from the screen & connect it into something going on in your life. It sure did to me.

Amazing cast with an amazing dialogue. I'd say it's more of a romance drama, with comic moments. This movie is so real, and emotional. The characters faced real life problems in real life ways.

I usually go for the lovey dovey, the easy romance and tacky funny scene. Don't get me wrong I am all for it, but this movie took it to the next level. It made me think, it made me feel.

I hate to see all the low reviews! It definitely deserves better. Will definitely watch again.
It's not an easy story, but it shows real problems and people with tough challenges, with a hopeful and sensitive ending. This probably made it the film not so popular.

The story line, eh Average at best. Performances by Reese Witherspoon and Paul Rudd ,OK Far far from Award-winning. But Jack Nicholson ,his performance is worth every bit of sitting through the rest of the movie ! It's worth a watch just to see him do what he does best.
Have to say Paul Rudd (George) is hysterical 👍 The writing is really good and Witherspoon is SO believable as a sports girl 👍 Loveable as always she's amazing and fun to watch 👍

As stated before, this film at least in my opinion was highly underrated. At first it seemed like the acting would fall short but by the end I was a fan. It was weirdly deep and witty even through the quirky comedy used through out the film. There seemed to be quite a few scenes that everyone can relate to and laugh about. I can't say that it was predictable which is a nice change from many other romantic comedies. I'm sure many writers will appreciate the witty humor used in the film. I thought James Brooks did a really good job!! It is sad to see these types of films get overall bad reviews but I can somewhat understand why. It's not your common "feel good all the way through" type romantic comedy. I can see how this movie might not be for everyone just because the protagonist and antagonist are not so clearly defined until the middle/end but I thought it made it more interesting and kept me watching.

review_title: Okay romantic comedy that ask the question what if? Or does it love and relationships are complex it leaves you guessing.
review_detailed_main:
Romantic comedies are okay and this one "How Do You Know" entertains with it's all star cast and it proves love and relationships are complex, yet still in the end it leaves us asking for answers. Still it was good seeing America's sweetheart the beautiful Resse Witherspoon at work and it was nice to see my favorite actor the man legendary Jack Nicholson back again even though the role was small.

Witherspoon is Lisa a young beautiful girl who's passion is playing softball and even though she fails to make the USA team she still has plenty to live for. As Lisa is making love with a rich stud major league baseball player Mat(Owen Wilson)and she moves in with him still at times she feels that role is a little to demanding.

To add to the problem is George(Paul Rudd) a guy who has befriended Lisa yet he has a slew of his own problems as he's under federal investigation for money fraud and shady dealings, yet it was all done by his cocky and arrogant father Charles(well done and suited by legendary Jack Nicholson).

Thru it all love spats and phone tag is played with tears, and uncertain chats in this romantic comedy. It's something that is entertaining as it proves love and life is complex as we never know our love status day to day? Anyway it was good seeing America's sweetheart beauty Reese Witherspoon and it was nice again seeing the man legendary Jack still this picture though enjoyable from James L. Brooks left to many questions to be answered it left me wondering what if as it never really answered it's title "How Do You Know".

review_title: Sweet movie highlighting the complexities of love
review_detailed_main: I really enjoyed this movie since it portrayed successful people having real and sometimes conflicting feelings on serious matters and what types of actions to resolve them, oftentimes in a unique way. I was left with a positive feeling. The acting was good and it was a refreshing break from a typical Rom Com endeavor. Too bad it was not a commercial/critical success.... It should have been.

First encounter with Mr. Rudd, loved the whole idea and concept, loved his acting. I've been to that tiny corner of the universe shown by this movie and would return there in a flash. I really like this movie. 10 stars and 5 quick reasons none of which really encapsulate my love for the movie.. 1. I can watch it over and over without losing attention... Cause or effect?...?

2. Rudd and Witherspoon do a great job of acting.. 3. Plot is out of the ordinary 4. Love the banter, I need to see that at least 10 more times 5. It shows a disturbing part of human behavior that many will cringe at, i.e. How decisions are really made... in short, "How do You Know?" :) I think you will find that people not at ease with their own lives, will find this movie down right mean and irritating. Sorry about that. Show it to me some more :) I positively love it :)

A little addition... The writer made the dialog for the actors pretty much the same, a typical problem with fast writing projects, bit scatological, and with much the same speech patterns, noun-verb order, paragraph continuity, etc. I noticed that some were bothered by this in the reviews but seemed unable to specify the problem. I kind of liked it, it gave the movie some continuity in a world normally without. This sort of thing also happens in communities, speech and thought patterns learned over a lifetime.

review_title: She loves me, she loves me not. Feel good, romantic and funny! Great, last role of Jack lifts this romantic comedy up!
review_detailed_main:
Terrific great quirky romantic dialogues between Reese Witherspoon, Paul Rudd and Owen Wilson are the core of this funny and feel good romantic comedy. The story in short is about Reese Witherspoon being in constant doubt if she has met the right guy. How does she know if the seemingly perfect and succesful Owen Wilson is the right guy for her to be engaged to? That's the cliffhanger with the dorky looser Paul Rudd being the OTHER guy that is vying for her love. Not a difficult choice to make, one might think...?

What makes this movie extra special is the terrific supporting role of Jack Nicholson. Jack is still THE man. Only featuring some 15 minutes of screen time, but when he is on, Jack is ON.

Director James L. Brooks has made some other classic feel good romantic movies: "Terms of endearment" and "As good as it gets". Anyone familiar with these 2 romantic classics knows this director has got the romantic touch, that will melt everybodies heart. Highly recommended for those who just long to see a quirky feel good romantic comedy. Enjoy!

How Do You Know happens to be among my all-time favorite comedies. The chemistry between Reese Witherspoon, Owen Wilson and Paul Rudd is unmatchable. Jack Nicholson does an amazing turn as well. Even minor characters like Reese's baseball coach does a great job. I loved her remark about "smiling at bastards". Lenny Venito in the hospital scene outshines many great actors. Absolutely brilliant, and so spontaneous. That entire scene is so meaningfully and empathetically shot it is nothing short of a masterstroke. The dialog in that scene had me by the pulse from second-to-second.

And Owen Wilson plays his character beautifully as a successful yet self-centered baseball player. His epiphany when Reese is walking away from him to the elevator is beaut of scene and echoes the reality of break-ups from the male perspective meaningfully.

I loved Paul Rudd's vignette scene about playdoh, it still resonates so freshly in my mind even though I saw the movie some years ago. Of course I have by now seen the film at least thrice.

Paul Rudd's and Reese's interactions at his cluttered apartment are a sheer pleasure to watch. I loved the line "it's the opposite of a bus strike".

How Do You Know is an amazing comedy if you know your comedies. Perhaps it's complexity may put some people off but I found it a sheer joy to watch from start to finish. Highly recommended.

If you're looking for a pick me up, this is it. Its not a rom com, but it has romantic and comedic charm to it. It really is just a story, a story that just about anyone can find themselves relating to. That being said, I don't think I've seen a character written quite like Reese's portrayal of Lisa. A character who isn't obsessed on one certain goal in her life (ie finding the "one", getting a certain guy's attention, etc). Instead she just goes through life, working through her problems and dealing with them in an honest way. Even when she bumps in to George (paul rudd) she doesn't upheave everything about herself, instead she continues about her life's mess and works with what is given to her. I personally found her thought process, decision making, perspective, and overall character to be refreshingly relatable. Of course, I can't resist the charm and loveliness of Paul Rudd, and playing George Madison is just another role he excels at playing for this movie.

The rest of the movie I'll save for those who watch it, but just know if you're looking for a feel good movie with some laughs, romantic charm, and a good following of characters while feeling like a fly on the wall to their situation, How Do You Know is a great movie for just that. The writing could be a little sharper, sure. But if you're irritated by the forced emotion in writings of today's movies like I am, this movie will not bother you. Don't let the overall low IMDB rating number fool you.

review_title: Overall good acting and script. Shouldn't be rated so bad
review_detailed_main: This movie doesn't really have a gripping story line. Its the script that makes it good. You need to watch it a few times to get it all in. Overall Wilson does an incredible job at being "that guy" and Rudd, well he does his thing good. Acting is awesome cause well the actors are all stellar. An easy going watch. I think everyone reviewing bad here wants all the drama in the world instead of a real life look at stuff. Not every romantic story ends like princess bride.

review_title: Seriously.... This is a good movie
review_detailed_main: It bothered me to read so many bad reviews from people stating that they thought the dialog and/or story was all over the place. I don't agree at all. I found the writing and the delivery intelligent and refreshing. Frankly, I'm tired of all the regurgitated rom-com movie plots, especially when they have a sappy, all works out in the end. This movie breaks away from that mold and then leaves the intelligent movie-goer with a good idea of what the future holds for all the main characters.

Reading so many bad reviews, I hope people who can enjoy superb script, and excellent acting won't be discouraged from watching this movie. I gave it a shot & so glad I did. It is a wonderful gem among all the garbage movies that have been made in the last 20 years.
The best love story ever. Reese Witherspoon is such a great actor. Paul Rudd is so amazingly comical tragically! Owen Wilson plays a real soft-hearted man-boy!

review_title: I rearly review here- but I had to
review_detailed_main: This score- 5.4 (as I write this) is simply heartbreaking for me. such wonderful text, so much heart and soul. I feel bad for all the people who took part in this gem of a movie. If you have a heart and if you are not afraid of your feelings, watch it. I watched it after reading a review here and now I am so thankful!

Great cast, script, and movie. It's a romance comedy. It's not entirely predictable, and you can't help but love the characters or the actors I'm so glad they did it. My rating it's in comparison to rom/com movies. I like most of them, and this is one if the better ones I really don't think anyone would be disappointed.

This is actually the best love story I have seen in years. It reminded me a little about the movie Frankie and Johnny from the 90ties, I don't know why but it was something about the way it made me feel. It was simple but moving. It was funny in a subtle way. Paul Rudd was amazing, and Reese Witherspoon too. I really believed that he was in love and I felt it. I can't believe so many people has rated this movie so badly. I just started watching it not knowing anything about it, and if I would have checked here and seen all the bad reviews I might have missed it. I'm so glad i didn't. Made my night.

I love it, great feel good movie and the last time Jack Nicholson acted so that's nice! James L. Brooks is incredible at his craft I especially loved Definitely Maybe that he directed a few years before this. How Do You Know is a little off I understand the hate but it's a fun story and well made I really appreciate the smooth directing. Odd how they kept in moments that should've had a re take like when Paul Rudd falls down the stairs, or how early on Reese gets hit by a baseball when the phone rings stuff like that is unbalanced otherwise I really like the movie quite a lot and deserves better!

review_title: How do you know? It may surprise you, but it shouldn't.
